title: invitations downing street flat party
story: Invitations to Downing Street flat party went out across Whitehall, claims CummingsDominic Cummings - who quit as a top adviser the same day - said the event had been an "organised party" for which their had been formal invitations. London was under Tier  restrictions at the time Image: PAByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Invitations to a party in Boris Johnsonaposs flat while London was under Covid restrictions went out aposacross Whitehallapos, Dominic Cummings has claimed.The Prime Minister on Wednesday denied a party had taken place in his residence above  Downing Street on November , while London was in Tier  restrictions. But Mr Cummings, who quit his job as one of Mr Johnsonaposs most senior advisers the same day, today accused the PM of lying about the soiree. He said the event had been an organised party, for which there had been formal invitations.Mr Cummings was asked about the party during a QA on his £-a-month Substack website. Asked about PMaposs claim there was no party in the flat on November , Mr Cummings wrote: Obv he was lying. He went on: There were invites sent across Whitehall, it was an organised party. [Johnson] know[s] this and tried to lie his way out, but was f****d by the video.  The video in question was a leaked clip of former Johnson spokesperson Allegra Stratton joking about a later party in Number , on December . Earlier, Mr Cummings tweeted: Thereaposs lots of pictures of the parties which will inevitably get out. And invite lists beyond No to other departments. And he had referred to reporting published at the time that there had been a victory party in Downing Street following Mr Cummingsapos leaving No. On November  , the Mail on Sunday reported claims there had been boisterous gathering in the flat, as allies of Carrie Johnson celebrated his departure. Allies of Mrs Johnson - then Ms Symonds - denied the reports at the time. And asked whether the party took place at PMQs on Wednesday, Mr Johnson said: No.Yesterday, it was confirmed that as well as investigating the party held in Number  on December , a second gathering on Novmeber  would also be subject to a probe by Cabinet Secretary Simon Case. Tory Minister Michael Ellis told MPs that the investigation will establish the facts around events alleged to have taken place in Downing Street on November  and December . It will also look at a gathering at the Department for Education on December . All three events - which sources said took place despite Covid restrictions - were first revealed by the Mirror.The Prime Minister finally apologised on Wednesday after a clip emerged of his own staff joking about a “not socially distanced” bash on December  last year.  He announced a probe into the event by Cabinet Secretary Simon Case - but his spokesman confirmed that inquiry will only cover the events of December  last year. But Mr Ellis said on Thursday that it would cover allegations of a second No event on November  - during a national lockdown - where sources claimed Mr Johnson addressed a leaving do. Last night new polling gave Labour a six point lead over the Tories, as revelations over rule-breaking Christmas parties and sleaze hit Mr Johnson in the polls.An exclusive survey, conducted by Survation on December , after the Mirroraposs bombshell story about No aposs lockdown-breaking festive knees-up, sees support for Labour soar to %while the Conservatives slump to %. It represents a breakthrough for Keir Starmer as it is the highest poll lead for his party since Boris Johnson took power.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Plan BBoris JohnsonCabinetJohnsonsConservative PartyMail on SundayPoliticsChristmas party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: keir starmer tells tory mps
story: Keir Starmer tells Tory MPs to oust Boris Johnson amid Downing Street party rowThe Labour leader branded Boris Johnson unfit for office amid widespread anger about allegations of lockdown-busting parties in Westminster last yearKeir Starmer said Boris Johnson was unfit to lead Image: PAByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Keir Starmer has called on Tory MPs to oust Boris Johnson as the under-fire PM faces mounting anger from his own party. In his strongest comments yet, the Labour leader said Mr Johnson was unfit for office and asked Conservatives how long they were prepared to keep on defending the indefensible. The Prime Minister is battling on several fronts after a wave of damaging allegations that seven separate lockdown-busting parties were held in Westminster in the run-up to Christmas last year. Claims have now emerged that Boris Johnsonaposs top spin doctor Jack Doyle made a thank you speech and handed out spoof awards to Downing Street staff at a No festive bash on December . Sources have told ITV News that Mr Doyle, who was then deputy director of communications, held a joke awards ceremony for staff at the bash, which is now the subject of a Cabinet Office probe. Meanwhile, Mr Johnson is also accused of lying to a probe by his standards advisor Lord Geidt which cleared him of breaking rules over the refurbishment of his Downing Street flat.  And he faces a potential Tory rebellion over new Covid plan B measures, which include the introduction of vaccine passports for large events. Labour has vowed to back the measures, meaning they will pass, but dozens of Tory MPs have spoken out publicly against the plans. It comes as an exclusive poll for the Mirror found Labour has opened up a six-point lead over the Tories. The survey, conducted by Survation on December , after the Mirroraposs bombshell story about No aposs rule-breaking party, sees support for Labour soar to %while the Conservatives slump to %. Mr Starmer tweeted: Boris Johnson is unfit to lead our country.He also told The : Iaposm confident weaposre going to win the next general election, whether thataposs in  or .So the question - and this is really the question that I think is central now - for the Cabinet, for ministers and for all Tory MPs, frankly, is are they prepared to endure the next two years of increased degradation of themselves and their party, being put out to defend the indefensible and bringing themselves and their party into further disrepute  Because this isnapost going to change - heaposs unfit for office, it isnapost going to change. Or are they going to do something about it  Askedhe was urging MPs to overthrow the PM, he said: I think they have to make that decision. This isnapost going change. A senior Conservative MP said Boris Johnson needed to come clean on lots of issues - and warned he needed to dferentiate between his private le and public le.Geoffrey Clton-Brown, Treasurer of the powerful Tory backbench  Committee, warned the PM that he needed to come back refreshed after Christmas. The Cotswolds MP said: Heaposs got to come clean on a lot of the issues that you mentioned in your opening news.Weaposre all about to go for a Christmas break. If he comes back in the new year refreshed, able to dferentiate between his private le and public le, and clary all the issues and then start to do the really big issues that this country needs - restoring the NHS, dealing with carbon emissions and Cop, how we deal with the economy, helping businesses - we can really get onto that agenda away from these other, sort of, personal issues, then I think heaposs fine.Butwe go on having these - what I call personal issues, issues of judgment by the Prime Minister - then I think thataposs a very dferent scenario. Cabinet Secretary Simon Case has been tasked with leading a probe into allegations of three parties in Westminster after Mr Johnson finally apologised for a No Christmas party on December , first revealed by the Mirror.Mr Johnson told the Commons he was sickened and furious at a clip of his staff laughing about the Christmas bash four days after it happened - when lockdown rules banned social gatherings.  Downing Street stonewalled questions for a week and claimed there was no party, but on Wednesday the PM announced a probe and disciplinary action for any rule-breakers. Alongside the December  party, Mr Case will include in his review a confirmed gathering at the Department for Education on December  last year, and a reported leaving event for a No  aide - allegedly attended by Boris Johnson - on November . Small business minister Paul Scully said it was key to get to the bottom of the allegations. He said the probe had been launched as we want to see beyond doubt that there were no rules broken, which is what the assurances have been to the Prime Minister, and thataposs what Iaposve heard.I wasnapost there. I donapost know, he told BBC Breakfast.He added: Look, I feel very comfortable about the Prime Ministeraposs integrity. Clearly though, I donapost feel comfortable about the fact that itaposs been a dficult week for the Government. He refused to comment on reports the PMaposs top spin doctor Jack Doyle attended the December  bash and gave a speech. Downing Street has said the PM has full confidence in Mr Doyle to continue his role as communications director. AskedMr Doyle had offered his resignation, the spokesman said: Not that Iaposm aware of. Mr Doyle has been approached for comment. title: labour opens up astonishing six
story: Exclusive: New poll gives Labour astonishing six-point lead over the Tories after No partySurvation poll in wake of Downing Street Christmas party revelations sees backing for Keir Starmer soar to % - the highest since Boris Johnson became Prime MinisterLabour leader Sir Keir Starmer Image: PAByRachel WearmouthSenior Political CorrespondentAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsLabour has opened up a six-point lead over the Tories as revelations over rule-breaking Christmas parties and sleaze hit Boris Johnson in the polls.An exclusive survey, conducted by Survation on December , after the Mirroraposs bombshell story about No aposs lockdown-breaking festive knees-up, sees support for Labour soar to %while the Conservatives slump to %. It represents a breakthrough for Keir Starmer as it is the highest poll lead for his party since Boris Johnson took power. The last time backing for Labour reached %, with the same pollster, was January , , when Theresa May was PM and Jeremy Corbyn was at the Oppositionaposs helm.Ed Daveyaposs Lib Dems polled at % , while right-wing populist party Reform UK, headed by Brexiteer Richard Tice, represents a new threat to the Tories, taking % . Backing for the Greens was also up at % . Additionally, % of Brits surveyed believe the Government has worse standards than it had in previous years.And % said the Tories do believe there is aposone rule for them and one rule for everyone apos.It comes as the Prime Minister attempts to fend off a barrage of criticism over the secret festive bash on December  last year. The Met Police has ruled out an official investigation into alleged breaches of Covid rules, but the PM has asked Cabinet Secretary Simon Case to establish the facts. Leaked footage of staff, including the PMaposs former spokeswoman Allegra Stratton, joking about cheese and wine at the bash and definitely no social distancing, however, sparked fresh public anger about the get-together. Ms Stratton resigned on Wednesday after the video emerged. Meanwhile, the Conservatives are battling to hang on to power in a crunch by-election in North Shropshire after Owen Paterson quit over repeated and egregious breaches of lobbying rules. The scandal led to numerous allegations of Tory sleaze, with a string of MPs found to have lucrative second jobs as political consultants. Mr Johnson was also forced to U-turn on his bid to rip up standards rules. The Government could also be facing a backbench Tory rebellion over the PMaposs new plan B restrictions in Parliament next week. title: mirror shone light deceit high
story: Mirror shone a light on deceit in high places with Downing Street party scoopThe Mirrors story of Tory wrongdoing last Christmas while the rest of the country suffered acted as a lightning rod for all of our frustration and rage, writes Paul RoutledgeThe video of these highly paid jacks-in-office laughing and joking about their Downing Street party tipped this story over the edge into public outrage Image: ITVopinionByPaul Routledge:,  Dec | commentsPublic service takes many forms. I believe this newspaper made a signal contribution with our exposure of the Covid rule-breaking in Downing Street.The story of illicit Christmas parties among Tory aides last winter wasn’t just a journalistic scoop. It lanced the boil of deceit in high places.And it acted as a lightning rod for all the frustration and rage of people who have endured so much and feel let down by the government’s incompetence, duplicity and delay during  months of coronavirus crisis.When “Partygate” was made public, people who had lost loved ones reacted with understandable anger. Their wrath against “one rule for them, another for us” boiled over across the media. It all came out. We have seen a similar upsurge of voter disgust before. It swept John Major’s sleaze-ridden government out of office in . But this time it’s personal, directed against an inidual Prime Minister who they know is the chief architect of this scandalous state of affairs. The people’s fury has forced arrogant Boris Johnson out of his lethal lethargy. He was compelled to invoke Plan B-lite restrictions, against his own inclination and in defiance of his hard-line MPs.And he had no option but to set up an inquiry into the shenanigans in his own office. The investigation by Cabinet Secretary Sir Simon Case must not be another Whitehall whitewash. If the rule-breakers are not brought to book, public distrust with government will increase.  The politan police should also be jolted out of their supine indference to the antics of the Tory Bright Young Things who think the law is for “the little people” – like you and me. The video of these highly paid jacks-in-office laughing and joking about their Downing Street party tipped this story over the edge into public outrage.But none of this would have happened without the Daily Mirror’s disclosures ten days ago, which were repeatedly denied by the Number  lie machine.And still are refuted – by the very aides who partied way into the night while everyone  was compelled by law not to mix with their own family. Vomit-inducing. The time has come for someone – preferably Sir Keir Starmer – to stand up in Parliament and repeat the words of Oliver Cromwell to the Long Parliament in , and Tory MP Leo Amery to appeasement premier Neville Chamberlain in : “You have sat here too long for any good you are doing - in the name of God, go!” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative Partypolitan PolicePlan BBoris JohnsonPoliticsCoronavirusDowning Street Christmas Party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: nicola sturgeon urges people cancel
story: Nicola Sturgeon urges people to cancel Xmas parties amid fears of a tsunami of Omicron casesThe First Minister told Scots the new strain was a "very severe challenge" while Downing Street said "we do not think there is a need to cancel people coming together in hospitality venues"Nicola Sturgeon Image: Daily RecordByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Dec | commentsNicola Sturgeon has urged people to cancel Christmas parties and work from home as she warned Britain faced a tsunami of Omicron infections.The First Minister, who will attend a Cobra meeting on the pandemic with Boris Johnson and other leaders later today, told Scots the new strain “threatens a rapid and large surge of Covid- cases”.It came as Downing Street doubled down on its position on Christmas parties in England, saying we do not think there is a need to cancel people coming together in hospitality venues. The FM said the Scottish Government was acting as Omicron was set to overtake Delta as the most dominant strain within days, adding Covid could put signicant additional pressure on hospitals and other health and care services at the peak pressure of winter. “The fact is, we do face a renewed and very severe challenge in the face of of the new Omicron iant,” she said at a briefing in Edinburgh. “To be blunt, because of the much greater and faster transmissibility of this new iant, we may be facing – indeed we may be starting to experience – a potential tsunami of infections.” Meanwhile in Wales, First Minister Mark Drakeford also sounded the alarm over the new Covid strain, telling reporters at a briefing that restrictions would be reviewed weekly. The Department for Health said on Thursday there had been , new Covid infections and fears for the NHS are growing.The Prime Minister announced on Wednesday that England would move to Plan B restrictions, with people told to work from home as of Monday. The ramping up of Covid curbs also means more mandated mask-wearing and next week MPs will vote on a Covid pass scheme for some venues. But the Prime Ministeraposs authority has been damaged over the lockdown-breaking Christmas bash in No last December - first revealed by the Mirror. On Thursday night it emerged his communications director Jack Doyle gave a thank-you speech at the event and handed staff spoof awards.Tory backbenchers are also threatening a major rebellion over the Covid pass plan while Labour has said the PM is not fit to lead the country as the pandemic rages.Askedpeople in England should cancel their Christmas parties too, Mr Johnsonaposs spokesman said on Friday: Under Plan B, weaposre not shutting hospitality. The use of certication enables a number of venues to remain open when otherwise we would have had to close them for public health reasons as we have had to do previously. We understand fully the impact that these measures have had on hospitality in the past and certication allows them to remain trading. We do not think there is a need to cancel people coming together in hospitality venues. news politics plan-c-masks-indoor-spaces-"Coronavirus Headlines: Face masks plan for indoor spacesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsMinisters are already working on aposPlan Capos restrictions that could be introduced in the New Year with tougher curbsCovid cases continue to surge, it is reported. Boris Johnson has already suffered a backlash over Plan B rules aimed at tackling Omicron, which is predicted to become the dominant iant and could be more resistant to existing vaccines. Officials are now reportedly working on aposPlan Capos, which would go a step further by reintroducing the NHS Covid app check-in for people going to pubs and restaurants, making face masks compulsory in all indoor spaces and using vaccine passports for more venues.Mr Johnson’s Plan B has been criticised by businesses as well as many Conservative MPs and even some scientists who claim the measures won’t make an impact on the spread of Omicron.  It now means that people will need to wear face masks at indoor venues like cinemas and theatres or churches, and from next Monday new work from home guidelines will be introduced. MPs will vote next Tuesday on the plans, with a string of Tory MPs openly criticising plans to introduce vaccine passports. Businesses have seen themselves hit in what for many is their busiest period of the year over Christmas and New Year - but Mr Johnson says he hopes the measures will “slow the spread”. data-redesign-embed"true"The prime minister is expected to face a backlash from his own party during the vote next Tuesday, with the Daily Mail claiming that at least  MPs could go against him.The report claims ministers are considering aposPlan Capos rules such as forcing customers to use the NHS Covid app again to go to a pub or restaurant, making face masks mandatory in all indoor spaces, and having to show a vaccine passport at more venues. It comes with Mr Johnson under pressure over the alleged Christmas party at Downing Street last December that he had denied took place. There have been calls for him to resign and a poll has shown % thought he should go, it is reported. A senior Tory source told the I think we will get it through with opposition support, but there will be such a bloodbath within our party when the dissatisfaction sets in. Tory MP David Warburton was one of many to attack the Plan B saying it was confused, contradictory, arbitrary and wholly disproportionate. He said the insanity needs to end with the new rules not stopping people from meeting at the pub after work and that it has been suggested that people could take off their masks to sing. title: scots strongly urged cancel christmas
story: Scots urged to cancel Christmas parties just day after Boris Johnson said they were okPublic Health Scotland issues new guidance as "much more transmissible" strain of Covid- takes hold booster vaccination on December ,  in Glasgow, Scotland. " content"https:i-prod.dailyrecord incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" First Minister Nicola Sturgeon Image: Getty ImagesByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsScots have been strongly urged not to go to Christmas parties, just one day after Boris Johnson said they were OK to attend. Public Health Scotland issued new Covid advice today asking people to postpone their festive bash this year and do their bit to protect ourselves and our loved ones. At Wednesdayaposs Covid- briefing, Mr Johnson said Christmas parties could go ahead but that people should exercise caution. He said: Itaposs OK to keep going with Christmas parties but obviously everybody should exercise due caution, have ventilation, wash your hands, get a test before you go - give everybody  confidence they are going to be meeting somebody who is not contagious.” Downing Street will not be hosting any Christmas parties themselves this year, despite the PMaposs OK to go ahead. No officials will be focusing on the intensive work needed to tackle Omicron. There are also fears growing over the rapid spread of the much more transmissible Omicron iant.  It comes as the UK recorded a , new infections and the latest UK Health and Security Agency confirms  cases of Omicron north of the border. Dr Nick Phin, Director of Public Health Science and Medical Director, said a signicant number of Covid outbreaks in Scotland have been linked to parties. He said: “There is much that we still need to learn about Omicron, but early evidence suggests that this new Covid iant is much more transmissible. The impact of this transmissibility has been seen in recent weeks, with a number of Omicron outbreaks linked to parties. “We still need to learn more about the severity of disease caused by Omicron and the effectiveness of vaccines, but there are important things that we can do to help protect ourselves and our families now. To help minimise the further spread of Covid-, and Omicron in particular, I would strongly urge people to defer their Christmas parties to another time. “I appreciate that everyone is keen to celebrate this festive season, particularly after the pressures of the last twenty months, but by postponing some plans we can all do our bit to protect ourselves and our loved ones.” Throughout the pandemic, a tightening of restrictions in Scotland has frequently been followed by similar measures in England. Mr Johnson, meanwhile, is under increasing pressure after it was revealed Downing Street had a secret Christmas party last December, at the height of the second wave. He was forced to apologise after footage emerged of senior staff laughing and joking about cheese and wine and definitely no social distancing at the get-together.  No has confirmed they will not be hosting a party this year. A Downing Street spokesperson said: As the Prime Minister said Christmas parties can continue to go ahead under Plan B. Everyone should continue to behave cautiously and we recommend people take lateral flow tests before meeting others socially in high-risk settings, but it is up to inidual businesses and people to decide what works for them. No is focused on tackling the rise of the new omicron iant and the ongoing pandemic, and there are therefore no plans for a party while this intensive work is ongoing. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon had asked Scots to comply strictly with current protections, adding in tweets on Wednesday: And evenyou feel angry with a politician just now, please remember just how important compliance is for the health and safety of you, your loved ones and the country. Health Secretary Sajid Javid told the Commons this week that there was now community transmission of Omicron in all regions of England.On Wednesday, the Prime Minister announced the country would move to the governmentaposs Plan B plan for Covid curbs, with home-working advised from next week. It also includes more mandated face masks in places such as theatres and cinemas and a Covid pass system for large public events. Tory MPs will vote on the plans next week, with backbenchers set to rebel. title: what covid plan c what
story: What is Covid Plan C and what restrictions could be imposed to tackle OmicronOfficials are said to be looking at contingency plans amid mounting concern about the Omicron Covid iant. Here we take a look at so-called Plan C and what it means Image: Evening Standard   eyevineByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Dec | comments Tougher restrictions are being brought to tackle the spread of the Omicron iant as Boris Johnson implemented his Covid Plan B.The Prime Minister said on Wednesday that people in England should work from home where possible from December , while masks will be mandated in most public indoor venues from Friday. Vaccines passports will also be required for nightclubs and large events from December .But some experts have questioned whether the toolkit of measures will be enough to curb the new strain, with reports of officials drawing up Plan C with even tougher rules. Downing Street said on Friday there was growing confidence that the new iant spreads more quickly than Delta and there was some evidence of vaccine escape.Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon warned of a possible tsunami of infections ahead of a four-nations Cobra emergency meeting chaired by Cabinet Minister Michael Gove on Friday afternoon. Here we sort the fact from the fiction on future Covid restrictions in England. What is Plan C  Officially, there is no Plan C. The Governmentaposs Covid Winter Plan, published in September, includes a section on Plan B which has a string of measures to imposethe Covid situation worsens. Boris Johnson pulled the trigger on Plan B on Wednesday, with masks becoming mandatory for most indoor public spaces from Friday, and vaccine passports made a legal requirement for nightclubs and large events like football matches from Wednesday. Brits will be ordered to work from home againthey can from Monday. This was thought to be enough to keep the virus at bay over the winter, along with the mass booster programme. But the arrival of Omicron has changed things. Downing Street say there is no official Plan C amid reports officials are drawing up a contingency blueprint with more restrictions. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said on Friday there were no plans to go beyond what weaposve set out already when askedthere was going to be a published Plan C. But he added: Obviously we need to keep the characteristics of this iant under review, and we would actnecessary, but thereaposs no plans to go beyond what we set out. Askedthere was a Plan C document, he said: Not that Iaposm aware of. As a responsible Government, of course, you would expect us to... we have an array, already, of options available to us in terms of what measures we can take to mitigate a growth of any iant or virus. But there are no plans to go beyond that currently. What restrictions could be included in Plan C  There are plenty of restrictions that could come in to get infection rates down. Working from home is one of the big levers the Government can pull - and this is already coming into force next week. The other big one is a reduction on household mixing, which was mooted as a contingency plan back in October. However this would be highly unpopular and it doesnapost seem to be on the cards so far. Here are some of the ideas that could be in the pipeline. Hospitality check-ins Punters could be asked to use the NHS Covid app to check into pubs and restaurants, to help contact tracers track the spread of the disease. This rule was in place earlier this year as hospitality venues reopened after lockdown but it was later abandoned. Use of the app fell after the so-called pingdemic when hundreds of thousands of people were told to isolate, leading to staff shortages across a number of industries. In August the rules were changed so double vaccinated people no longer had to isolatepinged by the app. Instead they were advised to take a PCR testthey came into contact with an infected person.  Face masks in all indoor spaces Rules on face coverings have been tightened since Friday, to cover indoor spaces such as theatres and cinemas as well as shops and public transport. But officials are said to be considering making it mandatory in all indoor spaces, which would include hospitality too. Vaccine passports in more venues From December , people will have to prove they are double jabbed or have had a negative Covid test to go to nightclubs and large events like football matches. But this could be broadened to smaller venues too. The Government has been reluctant to require vaccine passports for pubs and other hospitality venues but this could be considered.  Tougher isolation rules Self isolation rules were loosened in the summer so double vaccinated people didnapost have to stay at home for  daysthey came into contact with an infected person. Following the emergence of Omicron, the rules were tweaked so anyone who is a contact of an Omicron case has to isolate regardless of vaccination status. Bringing back the -day rule could have an impact - but it would be controversial again. What would cause Plan C to be triggered  The Government usually refuses to say explicitly what thresholds need to be met to lead to new restrictions - as the situation can change rapidly. But we can take some educated guesses based on the Winter Plan and previous lockdown rules.Throughout the pandemic, one of the key aims of restrictions is to prevent the NHS coming under unsustainable pressure. Hospitalisation rates are a key thing to watch for as large numbers of people being admitted onto Covid wards would put the health service under strain. How well vaccines are working is another critical factor, as the protection offered by the jab has allowed everyone toto some semblance of ordinary le. One of the big unknowns about the Omicron iant is how well the existing vaccines work against it. This is what scientists are currently trying to find out. The transmissibility of the new iant is also important - and how sick people are becoming from it. The new iant may seem frightening but it is worth remembering that we didnapost have the vaccine last winter, which is the best protection against the virus. When could that happen  The short answer is we donapost know. Experts are still working to understand the new iant and the scientic advice will be critical to whatever decisions the Government makes. There are some indications that the new iant may cause less serious illness than feared - but this could still have a big impact on the NHSit spread quickly and infects lots of people. There is also the political angle, as lots of Tory MPs are unhappy with the idea of further restrictions - so there could be some big parliamentary battlesthe Prime Minister tries to bring in fresh curbs. MPs will vote on Tuesday on the Plan B measures, which would be reviewed again in the New Year. However the Government can bring in additional restrictions soonerthe public health case is strong enough. title: i sterilised 32 combat excruciating
story: Exclusive: I was sterilised at  to combat excruciating period pain - Im no less of a womanChrissie Hadfield, , was  years old when she first experienced painful periods, after the birth of her first child. Shes since been offered morphine and Tramadol to cope with the pain - but was desperate for a permanent solutionChrissie first asked her GP about sterilisation when she was just  years old Image: Make The HeadlinesByTfany WallisJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsA single mum-of-two who suffered excruciating pain during her period has taken the drastic step of being sterilised - at just  years old. Chrissie Hadfield first started suffering from painful periods and ovulation pain when she was  years old, after the birth of her oldest child. Each time her period came, she describes feeling a pain like a hot blade in her abdomen, leaving her doubled over in pain and unable to stand. She would also develop thrush each month and had poly-cystic oies - one of which was inflamed. After two dficult pregnancies with her  and eight-year-old children, she decided she wasnapost going to have any more kids. And when her youngest was born, she ended up in hospital with ovulation pain. She was given morphine to manage it, but doctors couldnapost figure out what was wrong with her.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here She said: “Over the next  years, doctors put me on every form of contraception you can think of. “They thought the contraception would help control the bleeding and help control the pain but none of them did. Anything hormonal literally wiped me out. She added that her period pain was so bad, she was once given drugs only given to women in labour. Eventually, she had a non-hormonal coilfitted, but this made her periods irregular and meant she could be bleeding for  days out of the month. I could also feel myself ovulating. It felt like a metal ball on fire rolling down my abdomen and every now and again it would shoot spikes. It was extremely painful.  When she reached  years old, Chrissie decided enough was enough and, knowing she didnapost want to have any more children, she asked her GP about sterilisation. But she claims her request was met with dficulty and was told it would be tricky for a single woman of her age to have the operation. “I had to show that every form of contraception does not work for my body, the hormonal contraceptives give me mental health problems and my body rejects the non-hormonal coil, she said. “I had to keep the copper coil, so I was on some form of contraception, but I was developing bacterial vaginosis and thrush every time I had a period, so I was given antibiotics every month.” Chrissie was also worried about the long-term damage taking so much medication each month would have on her body. She explained: “Being on this much medication is unnatural. Each cycle, I was developing cysts on my oies and tubes and a scan showed I had a right inflamed oy. “So, the thought of having sterilisation to me was a dream and a way out from all the medication and no more contraception. Hopefully an end to my pain.” The dficulty she experienced with her GP was repeated when she told people she wanted to be sterilised.In a Facebook post, she wrote: Back in February I expressed that I had been put on a list to be permanently sterilised. Not just because I didnapost want more children, it was mainly for health reasons.But I expressed how other peopleaposs opinions were the reason I was keeping it quiet because everyone was so vocal about their own concerns. She added: “I haven’t given into this decision lightly, so negative comments about my age or situation haven’t helped. I know sterilisation is final, I know how old I am, and I know I have made the right choice. “I have made this decision for myself. It seems to be natural for a man to have the snip, but a woman taking ownership of her own body is frowned upon.  Even to the point I was told yesterday by another woman during my pre op assessment... you know your partner could get the snip instead  I’ve had men not even knowing what a fallopian tube is and women telling me Iaposm making a mistake because ‘whatI meet a man who wants kidsapos  Responding to these comments, Chrissie says people arenapost conscious of what she wants and needs, given that sheaposs suffered excruciatingly painful periods for  years. People just hear sterilisation and jump straight away to judgement. Especially as I was single when I started this journey, she wrote. But finally, last month, she had the operation to remove her right fallopian tube and part of her left. “Does it make me less desirable because I canapost bear children  Does it make me less than a woman  Will it make me seen as a short term partner instead of a long term partner  “What will people think  Will people pity me because of my situation  Will I regret it  But you know what, I feel relieved, and I feel empowered. “Finally, a step to try and ease the pain I have been experiencing for years. All that worry was about what other people thought again. But I have a boyfriend who is amazing, she wrote. She encouraged people not to judge what others do with their own bodies - and remember that thereaposs a lot we donapost know about what others are going through.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcNow in recovery, Chrissieaposs pain hasnapost fully gone away, but itaposs more manageable. Now, she wants to promote equality around fertility issues. She said: “We are approaching . These should not still be issues women are facing to take control of their own bodies. “Nearly every woman has quoted to me, ‘my body my choice’ and I feel empathy for all the women who have thanked me for speaking up about my own experience, as it has given them confidence to speak up about their own. “Being sterilised shouldn’t make me any less of a woman,anything it gives me the ability to be more human.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSHospitalsPeriodsFertility" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: aliens already visited earth according
story: Aliens may have already visited earth, says bombshell report by NASANasa indicated it is open to the idea that extraterrestrial le exists in a report released in November under the Freedom of Information Act.Nasa is working to find unmistakable signs of le beyond Earth, it saidByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsAliens might have visited Earth already, according to Nasa which is working to find unmistakable signs of le beyond our planet. The organisation said while it is yet to find any credible evidence of extraterrestrial le, it is not closed to the possibility that aliens exist. It comes from a Nasa report released in November under a Freedom of Information request from GovernmentAttic.org. In a collection of emails, one Nasa official said the earliest alien records are probably ,BC or  AD, or not depending on what science and comments we believe. This was written in relation to the unsolved mystery of a cooking pot in China which dates back to ,BCIts owner asked Nasa for an expert opinion on the potapossUFO artwork depicting symbolic language, hidden meanings, futuristic spaceships and clothes from a vanished civilisation.The official responded: YesI was an alien who visited earth say , years ago or anytime, I too would take a simple thing in front of me like a clay pot to record my visit in multiple aposlanguagesapos or symbols and dimensions and technologies... including D, D, D, D, D, and beyond any comprehension here now.  However, he concluded that the potaposs drawing which defies the laws of physics, showing and aircraft with no motors, wings or tails, must be a unique coincidence. The document also addressed reports of unidentied aerial phenomenon, more commonly known as UFOs. It stated: “When we learn of unidentied aerial phenomena, it opens up the door to new science questions to explore. The language of scientists is data. But without access to full data, it is nearly impossible to very or explain any observation. It went on to highlight that scientic study of UFOs is facing a central problem being the lack of robust data including the lack of access to information that already exists. The revelation comes after a Pentagon report in June revealed what the US government knows about a series of mysterious flying objects that have been observed in military airspaces in recent decades. It looked at  records of sightings of what the government described as an unidentied aerial phenomenon or UFO.  Investigators were able to explain only one of those encounters which was attributed to airborne clutter. There was no evidence which pointed towards aliens or a major technological advancement by a foreign territory, such as China or Russia, as a viable explanation for the sightings. A senior US official said: Of the  reports we are dealing with here, we have no clear indications that there is any non-terrestrial explanation for them, but we will go wherever the data takes us. We don’t have any clear indications that any of these unidentied aerial phenomena are part of a foreign collection programme and we don’t have any clear data that is indicative of a major technological advancement by a potential adversary. Signicant efforts continue to track such developments and officials continue to watch that very carefully they added. Another senior official said that  of the reports show UFOs “that appear to have some sort of advanced propulsion or advanced technology. They also indicated speeds beyond what the US considers to be possible in the realms of foreign adversaries despite having a lack of propulsion or acceleration. title: baby boy born disorder rare
story: Baby boy born with disorder so rare it doesnt have a name with mum in race to save himLeo was born in March and requires round the clock care as he suffers with has epileptic seizures and low muscle tone, which means he has dficulty moving and breathingLucinda Andrews with her son Leo Image: Tim MerryByLucy Williamson:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA mum has said she is in a race against time to save her son who was born with an ultra rare genetic disorder so rare it doesnapost yet have a name.Lucinda Andrews, , had her son Leo in March this year after a ‘perfect’ pregnancy, MyLondon reports.But when doctors noticed Leo had no muscle strength at all in his limbs, Lucinda knew something was wrong. Leo is  of  in the world to be diagnosed with a TBCD gene mutation that affects his brain, central nervous system and muscles. Leo spent nearly four months in the ICU at St. Thomasapos hospital in Lambeth, before being discharged as doctors didn’t know anything more they could do to save him.  Lucinda, who now lives in Chatham in Kent, said: “It was completely unforeseen. When he was born, I was in complete shock. The severity of it didnapost really sink in. I donapost think it really did until I saw him in the incubator with all the tubes and wires. I just burst out crying. “Nothing that could be done because of the rarity of the condition. Even specialists out there that havenapost even heard of this disorder. “Then he was discharged. I was told to enjoy the time that I have with him. Leo requires round the clock care as he suffers with has epileptic seizures and low muscle tone, which means he has dficulty moving and breathing.  Overnight he requires ventilation, which kicks in when he stops breathing when is in a a deep sleep. Lucinda previously worked in hospitality while working abroad in Canada, but came back to the UK have Leo and now is a full-time Mum to him. Despite doctors presenting the option to turn Leoaposs le support machine off in the beginning, Lucinda chose to fight for Leo. While she praised doctors who did their best for him, Lucinda says she “just couldn’t accept that there was nothing that could be done for her son. “I have sent thousands upon thousands of posts and emails all over the world to try and find someone who knew more and could help.” she said. “It’s a deteriorating condition - he will get progressively worse. It could get to the point where he’s too weak to breathe. But I want to get help before his health declines. He is definitely defying the odds right now - I hope he continues to.  “I’ve helped him with physio somewhat - I can get him as strong as physically possible, but without medical help, thereaposs only so much I can do. Due to the rarity of Leo’s conditions, there are very few medical experts on the condition. This also means she is left in limbo, with no one being able to say for sure how long Leo has left. But, despite having no medical background, Lucinda says her fight for Leo engulfed her in research in a bid to do anything that will help him. She said: “I had no medical background before this, but you do become an expert in your child. I have sat down for hours and looked at medical results. I would google each word I didnapost understand and try and put it together in a simplied form to understand what it actually means. I would research how a specic diet might help him, or supplements to make him stronger.  “But I get days when I just feel like Iaposm losing the fight for him. Iaposll pick him up from his cot and hug him and cry. But I use that for my motivation to keep going. I put all that negative stuff to the back of my mind.Lucinda has found some hope in a US biotech company who can research ‘drug re-purposing’ for Leo - whereby drugs to treat other conditions might have unintended benefits. They can also undertake revolutionary treatment to change Leoaposs failing gene to produce the protein that he is lacking. But the treatment costs £, - so she relying on fundraising.  He is my motivation to keep going, Lucinda added. Lucinda has also managed to connect with some of the other parents whose children have the same condition - of which there are only  in the world. She said: They are mostly in the States but thereaposs one in Peru, a couple in Turkey. One mum in particular I became very good friends with and we bounce ideas off each other. She’s been a real rock.You hit so many brick walls when youaposre trying to find a specialist or raise funds to help. She’s been a real pick me up to me.”You can donate to Leoaposs fundraiser andabout his story here. title: britains first vegan butcher unveils
story: Britains first vegan butcher unveils plant-based Christmas dinner - but it costs £The hamper includes plant-based "turky", "peegs in blanket" and stuffing, as well as roast potatoes, sprouts, carrots, cabbage, Yorkshire puddings, gravy, mixed green, mash and gravyRudy’s ‘Royal Christmas Meat Feast box’ serves two people Image: RudysByLucas Cumiskey:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBritainaposs first vegan butcher has unveiled a fully plant-based Christmas dinner costing a whopping £. Rudyaposs aposRoyal Christmas Meat Feast boxapos serves two people and is packed with plant-based twists on Yuletide favourites. The pricey hamper includes plant-based turkaposy, peegs in blanket and stuffing. It also contains roast potatoes, sprouts, carrots, cabbage, Yorkshire puddings, gravy, mixed green, mash and gravy. The posh pack-up will be delivered between December  and , according to the aposbutcherapos. Olie Barat raved: Such a great box. We immediately bought another for Christmas. The meat lump is amazing and great in sandwiches with pickle. The potatoes were lovely and crispy and everything was so perfect. And so easy too!  But carnivores such as Piers Morgan boycotted the business when it opened. The presenter slammed: A vegan butcheraposs shop... and people wonder why Iaposve written a book about the world going nuts.Rudyaposs is also selling another £ Christmas dinner box, which rapidly sold out after its launch last year.The business opened on World Vegan Day - November  - last year, causing queues around the block as vegans went crackers for its treats, and it sold out within one hour.  Itaposs based in leafy Islington, north London.It comes as a mum sparked a debate online, after revealing she refuses to have any non-vegan foods at her daughteraposs first birthday party.The mum-of-three explained that when her youngest was just three-months-old, they discovered sheaposs allergic to dairy and eggs and canapost eat them in any form without it making her very poorly.  So, for her first birthday, next weekend, the mum decided she wanted all food and drinks to be free from the ingredients she cannot eat, so that the youngster doesnapost end up accidentally eating something that will make her ill. We have spent so much time figuring out what she was allergic to and avoiding it, I wanted to have one day where we do not have to monitor everything she ate, the mum explained on Redditaposs AITA forum. title: can drink alcohol before after
story: Can I drink alcohol before or after my Covid vaccine - and what are the side effectsThe government is continuing to encourage people to receive their vaccines. With Christmas parties in full swing, people may want to knowthey can drink before they are given the jabCoronavirus vaccines can cause minor side effects and drinking booze may not help Image: Barcroft Media via Getty ImagesByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Dec | commentsVaccines are vitally important for tackling the coronavirus pandemic. The government hopes that despite new restrictions such as Plan B, as well as further restrictions possible in the form of aposPlan C apos, hospital admissions will be lower due to vaccinations.When the UK was forced to lockdown in  and early , most of the population was unvaccinated against the virus. Receiving the vaccine should not be too much of an inconvenience unless you are someone who may have a reaction to it. Some people have experienced brief, flu-like symptoms after receiving it, but most are expected to be fighting fit and are welcome to socialise after being vaccinated. So can you drink alcohol before and after your vaccine  Can I drink alcohol before or after having the Covid- vaccine   It is probably best to avoid drinking before and after the vaccine and you are only damaging yourselfyou have been drinking excessively. Alcohol may harm your immune response triggered by the vaccine by suppressing your immune system. If your immune system is slower to react, then the effectiveness of the vaccine could be impacted.  As for drinking after receiving the vaccine, people have been known to have side effects caused by the jab. Alcohol will not help any of these symptoms and is not a cure for feeling ill, it is just likely to dehydrate you and you will feel worse. Can alcohol affect the immune system   When a person is exposed to a virus, the bodyaposs antibodies are tasked with fighting off this illness. Healthier people with better and faster immune systems can fight viruses off more quickly. This is why older people are more at risk from viruses like Covid-, as their immune response is typically slower. Yale Medicine addiction medicine specialist Dr. E. Jenner Edelman, told Healthline: Alcohol has erse adverse effects throughout the body, including on all cells of the immune system, that lead to increased risk of serious infections.With COVID-, alcohol is likely to interfere with an inidual’s ability to clear SARS-CoV- and cause people to suffer worse outcomes. What are the side effects of the coronavirus vaccine   In February, around one in three people reported some kind of side effect from the vaccine, including some soreness around the area the needle penetrated the skin. Side effects are caused by the bodyaposs response to the vaccine and not the virus itself.Dr Anna Goodman of Guyaposs and St Thomasapos Hospital, in London, told the BBC that a heavier response to the vaccine does not mean you are more immune to the virus than others. She said: Because you have more fever, that doesnapost mean you are more immune. You canapost presume it to. People have been known to experience the following side effects caused by receiving the vaccine: Headaches Fever Muscle pain Feeling tired Nausea Chills Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Plan BImmune systemAlcoholCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dog walkers could face hefty
story: Dog walkers could face hefty fines of up to £, for breaking strict rulesWhile taking your dog off its leadpermitted in most UK parks and wooded areas, it is in fact illegal in some spots - something pet owners should be aware ofDogs typically need to be on a lead near roads, footpaths, carparks, play areas and certain ponds or streams at some times of the year Image: SIPA USA PA ImagesByAlice Peacock:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsDog walkers could be slapped with a hefty fine this holiday seasonthey’re not aware of strict rules which can cost pet ownersnot followed. While taking your dog off its lead is permitted in most UK parks and wooded areas, it is in fact illegal in some spots. In lieu of signs alerting you to restrictions, it is likely fine to let your four-legged friends roam free. However, dogs typically need to be on a lead near roads, footpaths, carparks, play areas and certain ponds or streams at some times of the year. Areas like flower beds, beaches and pitches are usually considered off-limits. And dog owners should keep a keen eye out for signs alerting them to the rules, in case of any other restrictions.  Local authorities also have the power to issue a Public Spaces Protection Order , or Dog Control Order, excluding dogs from certain areas or instructing owners to put them on a lead. These orders also set out rules regarding the maximum number of dogs one person can walk at one time, and rules about dog fouling. The order comes with a maximum fine of £, – which can be issued as a fixed penalty notice in place of a prosecution. Other things you could be fined for under this order include failing to remove dog faeces, not putting and keeping your dog on a lead when asked to do so, permitting a dog to enter land they’re not allowed on, and taking more than a specied number of dogs onto a land.  Other lesser-known rules include ensuring your dog is microchipped and wearing a collar and tag in public. Dog owners can face an unlimited finetheir pet is not wearing an identity disc while they’re in public, with those failing to follow these rules facing the possibility of being served with a -day legal notice. Failure to comply following such a legal notice could see owners fined up to £ per dog. title: dying mum just months live
story: Dying mum with just months to live sang Staying Alive at her own funeral she organisedGillian Kennedy, , was diagnosed with stage four pancreatic cancer in April - with medics telling her at best she could extend her le for  monthsGill, from Perth, Scotland, said she has spent around  hours having chemo but following her last treatmentByMelanie Bonn:,  Dec | commentsA dying mum held her own funeral after doctors told her she has just months to liveGillian Kennedy, , was diagnosed with stage four pancreatic cancer in April - with medics telling her at best,she tolerated  hours of chemo every two weeks and completed the  gruelling rounds of additional chemotherapy she could extend her le for  months.The mum-of-one then made the radical decision to host her own funeral surrounded by her closest family and friends. Gill, who worked as a supervisor in a legal office for  years, was given the crushing news that the cancer had spread to  parts of her body.She did not see a doctor face to face during the pandemic period and when her cancer was found following a private MRI scan, it was already active in  places in her abdomen, reports the Daily Record. Gill, from Perth, Scotland, said she has spent around  hours having chemo but following her last treatment – on Wednesday, the day after her living funeral – she will now take things as they come.  She told the Perthshire Advertiser she had worried about how her son of  and her husband would cope with organising her funeral after she passed away so decided to take an unconventional route. Gill said: “I started to plan my funeral myself. I discovered you could have an option described as ‘direct to ashes’. I did not want my son Ryan faced with a cremation service and a coffin. “Funnily enough, at first I planned a lunch at The Royal George, but I did not like the cake choice, meringues, they offered on the menu. Then I thought, ‘but I won’t be there, so it won’t matter!’ “That set me thinking: whatI was there, whatI could enjoy the gathering of the people who mattered  It was not as though I had lost my capacity to enjoy le as yet, but I had to act fast. “I brought in Maggie Robertson, a celebrant and so began the process of this living funeral.” It was held at Craigie Hill Golf Club on Tuesday and Perth City celebrant Dr Maggie Robertson gave an eulogy. Gill’s childhood friend Susan – who she met aged three – flew in from Texas and pals from Bannatyne’s gym danced in matching t-shirts and masks with Gill’s face on to a live version of the Dolly Parton hit  to , which was sung live by friend Veronica.  There were balloons, a special cake and cousin Kerri arranged a specially-made slide projection of favourite photo moments from her le. A raffle fixed up by fellow cancer sufferer Sandra raised £ for Gill and Robbie to make some memories together in the coming weeks. They plan to go for a break at Gleneagles. To huge applause and cheers, Gill got up and danced herself. The track was Staying Alive. She had saved her energy for this, her big day, attending her own funeral party. There was a meal, laughter and tears and husband Robbie stole the show with a wise-cracking stand-up comedy routine that made light of the very serious situation. A written farewell message from each person there was collected to be put into an album. Celebrant Dr Maggie Robertson , a member of the Good Le, Good Death group, had cancer herself, opting for a double mastectomy. She said: “It was truly amazing what happened for Gill on Tuesday. “She had everything you could wish for and she was on her feet, even having a bit of a boogie. “It was an inspiring occasion, filled with much happiness and unique moments that will live on in everybody’s memory. I feel honoured to have been a part of Gill’s day.”  The cake on Tuesday was an imaginative model of Gill, Ryan and Robbie all sat on a bench. Like they often are, as Gill loves a walk up Kinnoull Hill. Celebration Station in Perth had made the couple’s wedding cake so it was poignant that they also made this one for Gill’s living funeral. A generous group of Fair City and Perthshire businesses donated fabulous prizes to Sandra’s raffle which ensured a fund for Gill’s future happy times was made possible. They were Lorna Davies Florist, KL Nails, The Bulldog Frog, Delicious, Murrayshall House Hotel, Pit Stop Cafe, Donna’s Harbour Cafe, King James pub, Alex Cairncross Jewellers, Taylor’s Hair Luncarty, Willows Coffee Shop, Macrotrition, Latchbrand Domestic Cleaning, cleaning products from Rachael Rush, plus champagne, vodka and ious other gts donated from friends and family. Another friend, Leigh-Ann Neave, started an online fund to help boost family morale by buying a bench, for which nearly £ has been pledged. The bench GoFundMe can be found at: https:bit.ly dAIEZ Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON FuneralsCancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news exact-time-royals-exchange-christmas-"Royal family leaves Christmas Day service in SandringhamByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Itaposs less than two weeks until the Royal Family are due to pitch up at Sandringham for their Christmas get-together.The Queen is said to be looking forward to hosting all of her relatives after having to miss out last year due to Covid restrictions. Just like other families, when the likes of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Charles arrive for the festive season, they come laden with gts for each other.But the rule is reportedly the cheaper and cheekier the present the better - with all manner of wacky and wonderful gts exchanged over the years.  However, there is a very specic time when the gts are opened - and itaposs not when most people open theirs. Rather than race from their bedrooms on Christmas morning to open their presents - they actually do it the day before on Christmas Eve. In fact, the exact time the present exchange takes place is thought to be around pm in Sandringhamaposs white drawing room. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.The royals have to sneakily place their gts in the room earlier that afternoon, and it was apparently the late Prince Philip who would oversee proceedings.Former royal chef Darren McGrady said: The royals are of German descent so they weave in German traditions to their celebrations. After afternoon tea, they open gts on Christmas Eve, as is the German tradition.Some of the gts exchanged over the years have included a leather toilet seat for Prince Charles, a grow-your-own girlfriend kit for Prince Harry and a shower cap for the Queen with aposainapost le a b****apos emblazoned across it.Last month, it was revealed that Queen has told her family she is well enough to host Christmas at Sandringham after recovering from a back sprain.The monarch, , assured them she was feeling “far better” and is “looking forward” to the traditional festive get together at her Norfolk estate. It is understood the Queen will travel to Sandringham on or around Friday, December . Royal sources said it was likely she would make a -minute helicopter journey from Windsor, but insisted a traditional journey by train from London to Kings Lynn had not yet been ruled out. A source said: “The Queen has told everyone she is feeling far better of late and is very much looking forward to welcoming them for Christmas.“Like many other families, this will be the first time Her Majesty can gather with her extended family after being kept apart for so long due to the coronavirus pandemic.”Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON SandringhamQueenKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: four five adults go out
story: Four in five adults to go out of their way to be kind this Christmas, research findsFour in five adults are planning to spread Christmas cheer through kindness this year by donating to food banks and treating friends to treatsDonating to charities and food banks were the top ways people planned to be kind this Christmas Image: Getty ImagesByRob KnightGeorgie Hughes:,  Dec | commentsThe Christmas spirit is alive and well, with four in five adults planning to go out of their way to be kind over the holidays, research has found. A study of , people, who celebrate Christmas, revealed the top  ways they will be spreading cheer this month - including donating to food banks and treating others to festive drinks or a coffee. Looking out for vulnerable or elderly neighbours and singing carols in the community are also things people will enjoy doing for others during December.While spoiling friends and family in a Secret Santa, going above and beyond with Christmas dinner, and paying for someone’s meal in a restaurant made the list too. The study was commissioned by Costa Coffee which is giving away one million ‘free drink’ vouchers to selected Costa Club app members - so they can share a coffee with someone using the in-app ‘Gt a Reward’ .It also found a third are feeling more festive this year compared to last, with the average adult intending to carry out at least four acts of generosity a week over the Christmas period. A spokesperson for the coffee chain said: “The power of Christmas spirit is all about bringing people together. Whether that be in the literal sense, or in more recent circumstances, extending a token of appreciation virtually. The study also found that more than eight in  believe people are more inclined to be kind to one another during the Christmas season. Further feel-good acts include donating money or items to charity, and writing thank you notes in response to things others have done for them during the past  months. Carried out via OnePoll, the research found others intend to go the extra mile when buying gts this year. And some will purchase presents especially for vulnerable members of the community.Top  ways the nation is coming together this Christmas:. Donating money or items to charity . Donating to food banks . Treating a friend to a coffee . Buying a festive round of drinks . Writing someone a thank you note . Going above and beyond on Christmas presents . Spending time talking to those without family . Looking out for vulnerable lonely elderly people . Going above and beyond on Christmas dinner . title: geronimo alpaca didnt tb wrongly
story: Geronimo the alpaca didnt have TB and was wrongly put down by GovernmentPost-mortem tests have shown that Geronimo the alpaca, who was put down down by Government vets amid a campaign to save him, did not have tuberculosis, it is reportedHelen Macdonald fought a high profile battle to save Geronimo Image: Tom Maddick SWNSByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsGeronimo the alpaca, who was controversially put down by Government vets, did not have tuberculosis and was wrongly euthanised, it is reported. Helen Macdonald, , who owned Geronimo, fought a high profile campaign to avoid the alpaca being killed, claiming she was confident he was not infected. But she lost a long legal battle to save Geronimo and the animal was taken away by officials, protected by police, from Miss Macdonald’s Gloucestershire farm last August. It is said that she is now considering taking legal action against the Government. Post-mortem results have found that the alpaca was found to have no trace of bovine tuberculosis after all, the Daily Mail reported.Initial tests on the animal for bovine tuberculosis in September were inconclusive with no lesions found on the lungs or respiratory tract - the most common place for them to be with the disease. But the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairssaid that tuberculosis-like lesions were found on liver and lymph nodes. Further tests to discover whether Geronimo had the disease involving the examination of tissue samples for developing bacteriological cultures, have revealed that the animal did not have tuberculosis.  Geronimo, from New Zealand, was a pedigree alpaca worth £, who had won competition thanks to the quality of his black wool. The eight-year-old twice tested positive for tuberculosis in  but Miss Macdonald disputed the results and a long legal battle went to the High Court where the decision was to kill the alpaca. She claimed Geronimo had given  positives. Thirteen expert vets had called on Environment Secretary George Eustice to stop the killing so that further tests could have been made that could also serve as to give a better understanding of bovine tuberculosis. Defra previously said that while it had sympathy for the case it had to tackle tuberculosis and pushed ahead with the alpaca being put down. title: how lateral flow test you
story: How to get a lateral flow test and when you should take one to check for CovidWith the introduction of Covid Plan B putting new emphasis on the need to take lateral flow tests, it is vital you know when to take them, where to get them and how to understand themNew measures, under Plan B, mean that you may need to be testing with lateral flow kits more regularly Image: In Pictures via Getty ImagesByHarry ThompsonSEO Writer:,  Dec | comments As the government introduces Plan B, the nation is once again being asked to follow measures to prevent the spread of Covid as the new Omicron iant takes hold.The new rules will see ato guidance suggesting people work from home, making facemasks a legal requirement in a range of locations including shops and public transport, daily testing for close contacts of positive cases and Covid passes for nightclubs, unseated outdoor venues of more than , people and all venues for more than ,.Talking about introducing the restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the move was the, proportionate and responsible thing to do as scientists race to uncover the dangers of Omicron.The new regulations will see increases in the number of people needing to take lateral flow tests, with Covid passes validan unvaccinated holder has ed a negative lateral flow test in the last  hours. Hereaposs everything you need to know about where to get a lateral flow test, how to read the results and more. Where can you get a lateral flow test   The best place to start is to find outyou are able to get lateral flow tests through your workplace, school or university.However, this option wonapost be available to everyone, in which case they can be ordered from the NHS website.These lateral flow tests will be delivered to your home in a matter of days. If you are unable to use the online service, you can also order them by calling the free number  between am and pm. Luckily, the tests are generally free for all purposes apart from travel. You can also go and collect them in person at pharmacies like Boots or Lloyds, as well as some community centres. Getting tests in this way is also usually free. A pack has seven tests, one for each day of the week. And, in some cases, you will be able to get two packs at once. When should you take a lateral flow test   People who are socialising often should take lateral flow tests regularly, while the new rules also create more times when you need to take them. You mainly need to take lateral flow testsyou are unvaccinated and need a Covid pass, oryou are a close contact of someone who has tested positive, in which case you will need to test every day. If you develop Covid symptoms you will need to take a PCR test, but close contacts with no symptoms will still need to take lateral flows. They are best taken when you are due to go into an area where the spread of the disease is likely to be higher, like places with big crowds or where vulnerable people will be present. Make sure you take your test no more than  hours before the event you plan to attend for the best possible protection. Test results can be registered via the barcode strip by going on the government website. When does an infection show on a lateral flow test  The following day may often be too soon to checkyou picked up the virusyou are worried you came into contact with it. Antigen tests, like lateral flows, are less sensitive than PCRs and so require a higher viral load to show a positive result - this can lead to  positives. However,you do have a positive result on your lateral flow test, you will see a line against both the aposCapos and aposTapos markers on the test, rather than just on the aposCapos marker.So, two lines, eventhey are faint, mean you are positive for Coronavirus and will need to report this on the government website.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonPublic transportPoliticsCoronavirus testing" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news kate-middletons-huge-christmas-regret-"Cheeky Princess Charlotte refuses to handover flowers after Sandringham Christmas serviceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsRoyal fans will be looking forward to possibly seeing the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge take all three of their children to church on Christmas morning for the first time. In , Prince George and Princess Charlotte made their Sandringham public debut when they met well-wishers after the annual religious service at St Mary Magdalene. Holding their proud parentsapos hands, the two adorable children smiled and waved to dedicated fans who waited for hours to see them - and itaposs hoped Prince Louis might join them this year. During their appearance two years ago, Kate colour-coordinated the familyaposs outfits, and they all looked very smart in dark green. And while fans around the world loved their style, it turns out that Kate really regretted her outfit choice for the day, and even told one well-wisher she really shouldnapost have worn it. Kate looked stunning in a heavy grey Catherine Walker coat, with a green hat, bag and heels.But during a quick chat with -year-old fan Rachel Anvil, she admitted it was the wrong choice for the unseasonably warm weather. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Rachelaposs mother told : Kate was talking to my daughter about clothes and how she was feeling too hot, she said aposI really shouldn’t have worn thisapos. I’m there talking to Charlotte about dolls and my daughter’s talking about fashion with Kate. It wasn’t fake it was a genuine discussion, it was about a minute but it was tailored to my daughter, it was like speaking to a friend. They are totally dferent with the public.  Meanwhile, it has been reported that the Queen will be holding her usual family Christmas gathering at Sandringham this year and may make a public appearance for the first time since early autumn.The monarch and late husband Prince Philip spent last Christmas alone as they shielded at Windsor Castle and it turned out to be their final festive season together, as the duke died aged  in April.But it appears the Covid pandemic will not force the Queen, , to cancel her usual family gathering for the second year in a row. According to reports, she is planning to host her family at her Norfolk estate and may even appear in public for the first time in months. The monarch has been resting on doctors’ orders and only carrying out light duties such as audiences since spending a night in hospital for preliminary tests on October , and later spraining her back. She is also preparing to film her Christmas Day message to the nation.
