title: £283k investment for outdoor space
story: OVER pound, has been invested to improve services and outdoor space for people in Kircubbin.Stormont minister Edwin Poots was in the village last week when he met Ards and North Down Council chairman Mark Brooks.Two projects in Kircubbin have benefited from funding made available by the Leader NI rural development programme which is managed by the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs .Mr Poots began his visit in Kircubbin Green to view a completed project consisting of perimeter tree planting, new seating, planters and other landscaping works which have created a civic space, courtesy of an pound, grant.He then travelled to Ballycran GAC which received a contribution of pound, towards a pound, project which has created a new build community space that includes a multi-purpose indoor hall for after-schools events, parties, health initiatives, a gymnasium, dance studio and changing rooms.Mr Poots said the schemes represent an investment of pound, from DAERA which, coupled with other funds that have been levered in, brings the total investment to over pound,.ldquoThese schemes have helped sustain groups and provide enhanced community facilities and services for the residents, both young and old, of Ards and North Down, he continued.ldquoI am delighted that despite the many recent challenges brought about by the Covid- crisis these projects, like many other projects throughout the borough, havebeen completed. I want to thank all those involved for their hard work and dedication in bringing these to fruition.Cllr Joe Boyle, the former chairman of the Ards and North Down Rural Partnership, the local action group tasked with delivering the rural development priority funding, said the investment had made a very signicant dference to rural communities.He revealed that in total, pound.m of grant aid has been delivered to date across the council area, with a further pound, to be provided next year across  projects.ldquoThe programme has supported  businesses and helped to create  jobs to date, along with a wide range of basic Services and village renewal schemes which provide both economic and social value to our area, continued Cllr Boyle.ldquoWe remain very grateful to Mr Poots and his Department for assisting the local action group in administering this essential funding in our rural area.Ards and North Down Council deputy mayor, Robert Adair mdash who also participated in the recent ministerial visit mdash said it was fantastic to see ldquovery signicantinvestment in new facilities for rural communities.He added: ldquoThey will make a very real dference for local people and are a great boost to our rural economy. We are very grateful to the Minister and his Department for the funding and ongoing support..prettyPhoto

title: Bus station upgrade safety work on hold
story: PLANS by Translink to enhance safety standards at Downpatrick bus station have been put on hold until the New Year so the work wonrsquot impact at the busiest time of the year for the townrsquos heritage railway.Due to start this month, the planned work is part of a province-wide investment programme which will see investment in  stations designed to improve the safety of staff and passengers, with the work including the provision of new lighting, safety signs and protective bollards.In addition, some resurfacing works will be required to bus departure areas which will require a temporary reduction of bus stands, with all work undertaken in compliance with government and Public Health Agency recommendations on Covid-.As part of the investment programme, ten buses will be relocated from the Market Street depot to a nearby car park close to the Downpatrick and Co Down Railway.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Cllr John Trainor have welcomed news that work at the bus station has been put on hold and wonrsquot impact on the heritage railway which runs its popular Lapland Express this month.ldquoThe heritage railway have suffered horrendously over the past two years and is only just getting the opportunity to reopen, said Mr McGrath.ldquoRecent news that Translink would have had to move  buses from the station to the nearby car park adjacent to the railway just as the Lapland Express was due to run came as a real shock.Mr McGrath said he and Cllr Trainor know how important the Lapland Express is to the railway and the families who are going to enjoy it and made immediate representations to both Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Infrastructure Ministerrsquos office on the issue.The MLA thanked Translink and the local authority for working quickly to ensure the railway could operate its Lapland Express for families to enjoy the magic and joy of Christmas.Cllr Trainor said he was pleased that Translink agreed to defer the work until the New Year.He added: ldquoThis will give the team at railway the opportunity to make the most of the festive period and bring the magic and joy of the Lapland Express to all those families who enjoy it..prettyPhoto

title: Consider farmers when working on cycle path
story: THE needs of farmers must be taken into consideration as work progresses on a new pathway and cycle lane between Clough and Dundrum, a local politician has highlighted.Welcoming the Department for Infrastructure scheme, Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis said access for agricultural machinery in adjoining fields must be considered during and after construction work has been completed.Contractors are working on a scheme that will initially stretch between the Blackstaff Road in Clough and the Ardilea Road junction at Mount Panther, near Dundrum.The work involves widening a one kilometre existing footpath to provide an upgraded combined footway cycleway and take approximately six weeks to complete.Cllr Lewis described the project as a ldquowelcome investment for recreational tourism and outdoor leisure and welcomes the recreational tourism potential it will bring to the area.He described the investment as ldquomuch-needed and thanked Stormont infrastructure minister Nichola Mallon for recognising Clough and Dundrum as a gateway to the Mournes.ldquoThe creation of this cycle lane will develop a safe place for those wishing to enjoy outdoor leisure. I, like many other families, cycle with my we and three small children and this space and environment to enjoy that time together safely and without fear of accident or injury is a blessing, said Cllr Lewis.ldquoNewry Mourne and Down Council proudly supports active and healthy communities and this cycle lane connects the local council to Stormont in a collective effort to improve the health and wellbeing of residents through the promotion of cycling and the enjoyment of outdoor leisure.Cllr Lewis also congratulated his Slieve Croob colleague, Cllr Andrew McMurray, who has been proactive in ensuring the district is marked on the map in terms of provision of safe cycle routes.He also revealed that Cllr McMurray has challenged him to a timed lap of the new route when it opens and hopes the event will raise money for a local charity, while the duo have a bit of fun along the way.Cllr Lewis said he has asked the Department for Infrastructure to consider the needs of those who need access to agricultural land that runs adjacent to the new pathway and cycling route, during construction and when it is completed.ldquoLand along this particular route is utilised for barley, potatoes and grazing, with the ground rotated each season which means that the fields are regularly in use throughout the year, he explained.ldquoPolice regularly pull in farmers driving along this stretch of road requesting that they facilitate traffic flow by waiting in a lay-by, allowing the build-up of traffic behind them to pass.Cllr Lewis said he has asked the government department consider how itrsquos going to accommodate agricultural or slow-moving traffic, suggesting that the original lay-by structure in the area needs to be maintained and protected to allow for safe access.He added: ldquoThese issues certainly arenrsquot impediments nor am I seeking to cause an obstruction. I simply wish to protect the agricultural community who rely on safe and free flowing access to their land..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar community donates shoeboxes to children in need
story: THE big-hearted Crossgar community has rallied around again by sending an amazing  shoeboxes to children in need this Christmas.The effort exactly matched last yearrsquos number of boxes, which ended up being sent to Albania.For the third year in a row, the annual appeal was kindly hosted by Josephine Brennan King and her husband Carl King at Idanceirish Ltd at the villagersquos square.The Crossgar community has provided enough Christmas presents to cater for an entire school of kids between the ages of -. Some shoeboxes were also bought and packed online.The quality of items in the shoeboxes this year was very high, with an estimated value of around pound, worth of gts and donations inside all the boxes.Most people also included a personal and unopened letter and photo about their family and le in Crossgar, which the children will enjoy reading too.Local shoeboxes were sent to a refugee camp in the Middle East the year before.After being processed in Mallusk, along with , other shoeboxes from Northern Ireland, the local shoeboxes are now on their way to England where they will then be sent on to their chosen destination in time for Christmas.Anyone who signed up for notications with Operation Christmas Child UK will find out in February where their shoebox was sent..prettyPhoto

title: Delight at street cleaning services across district
story: TWO local politicians have welcomed moves to improve street cleansing services across the district.Downpatrick area councillors Cadogan Enright and Gareth Sharvin took part in a recent workshop organised by Newry, Mourne and Down Council to discuss the issue and both hope that sweeping changes will be implemented.Cllr Enright said the ldquodisparity between street cleansing services in the Newry end of the local authority area and Down district must becorrected, expressing alarm that nine housing estates in Downpatrick are not being cleaned by council staff.He said that since the former Newry and Mourne and Down councils merged in , he has campaigned for a unormed street cleansing service across the entire local authority area.Cllr Enright said it would appear that following the recent workshop to discuss the issue ldquowe are at last on the cusp of real change.He continued: ldquoIt is not acceptable that all the major estates in Newry like Bancroft and Drumalane are swept on a weekly basis but Downpatrickrsquos estates like Knocknashinna or those off the Vianstown and Saul roads have no cleaning schedule.ldquoIn a similar way, villages like Crossmaglen and Rostrevor get a weekly scheduled clean but there is no schedule of cleaning for villages like Strangford or Killough.rsquoCllr Enright mdash who organises community clean-ups in housing estates around Downpatrick every summer mdash argued that such initiative is not needed in they area where estates receive a council-funded weekly clean-up.ldquoCouncillors in the Newry area have been deluged by complaints about the withdrawal of weekly street cleaning in their areas and their cleansing service has been adversely affected due to the need to protect the refuse collection service throughout the entire Covid- pandemic, he explained.ldquoThis has meant that cleansing schedules in Newry have not been followed which I think has woken up the council to the issues we have in the Down area where most locations have no scheduled cleaning regime.Cllr Enright said given that residents pay the same rates as their Newry counterparts, they should be entitled to the same level of street cleansing services.In addition to greater attention being paid to residential areas, Cllr Sharvin is also keen to see more focus on cleaning play parks, explaining that the recent workshop was planned by council officers to discuss the issues being faced in providing an equal high standard of cleaning across the area.He claimed there is still a two-tier approach when it comes to district cleansing evidenced by the level of mechanical equipment available to staff in Newry and Mourne compared to that at the disposal of staff in the Down area.ldquoThe biggest area of concern raised with me is cleaning residential areas such as Seaview in Killough, The Links in Strangford, Malone Heights in Downpatrick and St Patrickrsquos View in Raholp, he said.ldquoCurrently, there is meant to be a six to eight week rotation of street sweeping in residential areas but, due to Covid and resource availability, this is nowhere near being achieved and is clearly visible to see. I am contacted about cleansing issues on a daily basis and while working with council staff a solution is found, butrobust processes and procedures were in place, this should be routinely completed and no major issues should arise.Cllr Sharvin says he is also keen to see greater attention on cleaning play parks, explaining that currently there is no formal process to do so and operates on adhoc basis.ldquoGiven the increase of use play parks during Covid and the councilrsquos objective to increase healthy living in our communities, itrsquos vitality important that we clean and maintain our play parks on a regular basis. Council officials have agreed to replace surface safety tiles at our play parks and I hope this programme will continue to be rolled out, he said.Cllr Sharvin said that following the recent workshop, council officers are to compile a report which will be discussed by councillors..prettyPhoto

title: District’s battering from Storm Barra
story: DOWN District was pummelled by Storm Barra yesterday with gale force winds and driving rain coinciding with a spring high tide to wreak havoc.Thunder and lightning was added into the heady weather mix with the storm conditions bringing down a number of trees along the coastline. There were reports of trees down on the Killough Road and Strangfford Road outside Downpatrick and the Cloughey Road in Portaferry.Driving conditions were described as ldquotreacherous in some areas with people advised to stay at homepossible.Delamont Country Park on the shores of Strangford Lough was closed by Newry, Mourne and Down Council with the local authority also suspending bin collection services due to the gale force conditions.The local authority said it was ldquoessential that people did not leave their homes, urging them to exercise caution and minimise risk, particularly along coastal areas. In addition, people were asked to keep abreast of Met Office advice.The Strangford ferry service was suspended for a time with the coastline battered by huge waves whipped by mph winds, with Newcastle hit particularly badly. The National Trust also closed the Murlough Nature Reserve.Waves crashed over the wall at South Promenade in Newcastle while the nearby harbour area also took a battering as it was engulfed by gale force winds and powerful waves.Pupils at St Patrickrsquos Primary School, Legamaddy, outside Downpatrick and St Patrickrsquos Primary School in Saul were sent home after a power failure and while no other major outtages were reported, lights flickered in a number of homes and business premises throughout the day as overhead power cables felt the full force of the raging storm.A yellow weather warning was in place until pm last night, with gusts of mph recorded at Orlock near Donaghadee.NIE reported that around , of its customers across the province were without power at lunchtime on Tuesday with the power company forced to bring in extra staff to carry out repairs..prettyPhoto

title: Finnebrogue monster 25st vegan burger now holder of Guinness World Record
story: AWARD-WINNING food producer Finnebrogue Artisan is now the proud owner of its very own Guinness World Record.The Downpatrick-based firm holds the title for the worldrsquos largest vegan burger.Made by  members of staff at the food producerrsquos site at the Belfast Road business park, the mammoth burger which weighed in at a whopping .kg and measured . metres in diameter.The world record attempt was critically observed and assessed by Guinness World Record adjudicator Jack Brockbank, while ex-Blue Peter presenter Radzi Chinyanganya provided upbeat commentary throughout the day.Anthea McAuley, Finnebroguersquos communications manager, explained that all the ingredients in the world record burger had to be veried as vegan.And the local firm mdash which was has won a host of accolades for its products mdash used its very own Naked Evolution Burger recipe which was launched in September.Of course the burger needed a tailor-made vegan bun to secure the record breaking title, with Finnebrogue working alongside Irwinrsquos bakery to provide it.Anthea said that to avoid food waste on the day of the world record attempt mdash and in line with the companyrsquos own policies and that of the Guinness World Records mdash some of the finished burger was donated to homeless charity, the Simon Community, with Finnebrogue staff also enjoying the burger for lunch.ldquoAll stages of the world record attempt had to be evidenced and veried by independent experts before the adjudicator would confirm a record was set, added Anthea.Sean Kearney, Finnebroguersquos innovation process manager, said the company was set a target weight of kg, but knew from the outset that it wanted to exceed that.ldquoThe team included representatives from new product development, marketing and engineering and together we designed and built everything, including a swing to aid turning the patty during cooking, he revealed.ldquoThat was perhaps the most challenging part of the record as we didnrsquot want to break the patty which took almost nine hours to cook so the day was long. However, when we added all the condiments and Jack revealed the weight of the burger, we were elated.The record-breaking patty is the equivalent of , of Finnebroguersquos Naked Evolution burgers while the condiments included kgs of tomatoes, .kgs of lettuce, kgs of cheese, kgs of tobacco onions, kgs of gherkins, kgs of Naked ldquoWithout the Oink rashers and kgs of sauce.Guinness World Record adjudicator Jack Brockbank congratulated Finnebrogue on its world record.He added: ldquoIt takes some considerable planning and organisation to pull off a feat of this magnitude.ldquoThey observed the strict guidelines provided by Guinness World Records to the letter and it was a pleasure to witness such a dedicated team at work..prettyPhoto

title: From Clough to the Caribbean
story: A FORMER Clough man sets off this Sunday on a gruelling ,-mile voyage across the Atlantic Ocean.Clive Rooney is taking part in the  Talisker Atlantic Challenge, one of the premier endurance rowing events in the world.Clive and his four team-mates depart from La Gomera in the Canary Islands on Sunday along with over  other crews and will hopefully arrive in Antigua in the Caribbean around  days later.It means spending Christmas and the New Year away from his family and enduring conditions which could range from Atlantic gales and  foot high waves to baking sun and energy-sapping heat.Therersquos also the sheer exhaustion of rowing thousands of miles across an ocean and living with four other men on a small boat for over a month.Cliveand his team-mates have trained hard for their epic adventure, but hersquos under no illusions as to what lies ahead.ldquoIt is going to be really tough, but I am confident we can get to the end of the race, he said.Educated at Down High School and the University of Ulster where he obtained a degree in Economics, Clive has lived in Scotland for the past  years and works as a production manager for a major recruitment outsourcing company. He and his we, Charlotte, live near Edinburgh and have three sons, Angus, Jack and Hector.His introduction to rowing came only six years ago when he took up skf racing. He competed at the  world championships in Strangford Lough where he won a silver medal and went on to win two gold medals at the  world championships in Stranraer.Clive admits to being highly competitive and that after winning world titles he was looking to take another step forward.A TV documentary about explorer Ben Fogle and Olympic rower James Cracknell rowing across the Atlantic fired his imagination and he signed up for the Talisker Atlantic Challenge in January  along with his medal-winning team-mates, Ian Baird, Duncan Hughes and Ross McKinney, plus a friend, Fraser Potter.They formed a team, Five in a Row, and then set about putting their project together, which involved the not inconsiderable matter of raising pound, to cover their costs.They managed to get the money and then obtained a boat, which, they were delighted to learn, had been rowed by three Scottish brothers in a previous Atlantic Challenge race.Clive says: ldquoIt was tough going, but we managed to raise the money. The boat is excellent, but we tried to lighten it as much as possible in order to make easier. Even so, we are putting in enough food and water to last a minimum of  days, plus our clothes and sleeping gear.The boat will also carry navigation and safety equipment, plus satellite phones to keep in touch with their loved ones and other competitors.During the voyage, three crew members will be rowing at any time, while the other two are resting, and safety harnesses will be worn at all times.ldquoWersquove trained hard and prepared well and I know that racing two kilometres in a skf race bears no comparison with what lies ahead, but wersquore all looking forward to the race, Clive added.Clive and his team-mates are hoping to raise pound, for the Reverse Rett charity, which supports children with Rett Syndrome, a neurological degenerative disease.Anyone wishing to make a donation is asked to go to visit https:www.justgiving fundraising ross-mckinney.prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  December 12%2C 2001
story: SAINTFIELD ndash Saintfield is in line for a new multi-million pound hotel development which is set to create up to  jobs. The Planning Service has formally approved the plan which will see the Rowallane Inn transformed into a new -bedroom complex.Confirmation that approval has finally been given comes over a year after plans to develop a new hotel in Saintfield were made public and initially rejected by local planners.Politicians were also split over the plan, but amended drawings for the multi-million pound scheme have now been approved and Down councillors will be asked for their views on the scheme during their monthly meeting next Monday night.The plans also include the provision of a newroom, dining area and a lounge bar and the businessman behind the hotel project is delighted the scheme has finally been given the green light.Mr Frank Kearney said he hoped there will be no further obstacles placed int he way of a scheme he says has major benefits both for Saintfield and Down District.ldquoI believe Saintfield is an ideal town for a major hotel and the location of the Rowallane Inn at one of the busiest road junctions in Northern Ireland lends itself to such a development, he added.DOWNPATRICK ndash Shots were fired during the attempted robbery of a Securicor van in Downpatrick on Monday morning. Police officers lying in wait at the Safeway complex on the Ballydugan Road fired several shots when a cash delivery man was threatened with a replica firearm.Two men were arrested at the scene and appeared at a special court yesterday morning on a series of charges.The drama began at .am as the van arrived to deliver money to the Safeway store. A firearm, balaclava and mobile phone were left lying in the car park which remained closed for several hours after the incident.A sliver Peugeot car, stolen in Richill, ended up in a lane way between Safeway and Rathkeltair House, and a second car was taken away for examination from the Ballydugan Industrial Estate.CASTLEWELLAN ndash Castlewellan Library has been closed following the discovery of asbestos in the building last week.The asbestos was discovered in the roof space of the building at the townrsquos square when a contractor was investigating an electrical fault.Tests revealed a slight rise in asbestos levels after a hole was drilled in the ceiling during routine electrical maintenance.South Eastern Education and Library Board officials immediately closed the building and contractors were called in to remove the substance.The upper floor of the building, which is used by a local playgroup, was unaffected by the substance but has now also been closed.Officials have now announced the introduction of a mobile library service while the building remains closed.Chief librarian Beth Porter said the library service had been left with no option but to close the library. ldquoWe must give priority to maintaining a safe environment, she added.SHRIGLEY ndash A number of workers at Shrigley tannery, who were laid off last month, have received a massive pre-Christmas boost.The Tannery has confirmed that staff laid off in November are now back at work, taking the number of employees at the plant to over .The lay-offs were blamed on a downturn in orders and while company officials said they were disappointed, they remained optimistic about the future.Shrigley Tannery, which is the largest primate employer in the Killyleagh area, is currently enjoying a busy spell and the companyrsquos managing director, Mr William McCullough, said the marketplace is in better shape than it was a number of weeks ago.He said the market situation in Hong Kong and China has improved and also revealed International Leathers is also working on contracts in the United Kingdom, Italy, Canada or Spain.ldquoWorkers who were laid off in November are now back with us to help complete a number of orders and while we are cautiously optimistic about the future, some of the contract work we are completing is due to run out in January, Mr McCullough explained.RAILWAY ndash A TEAM of professional consultants is to be appointed in a bid to safeguard the future of the Downpatrick Steam Railway.The move is one of a series local politicians have come up with to help address a number of problems at the unique tourist attraction which is currently in the grip of a major cash crisis.In a bid to ease the companyrsquos current financial dficulties, a Down Council committee is recommending the local authority provides pound, in funding, but has warned additional finance will only be provided when the company comes up with a detailed business plan plotting its plans over the next five years.Councillors say while they recognise the importance of the railway, they believe much more needs to be done in terms of marketing the attraction.They have called for the railway company to liaise with senior council staff in a bid to line the attraction with other tourist amenities in the area to safeguard its future viability.KILLYLEAGH ndash The firm behind the multi-million pound plan to redevelop the Gocean area in Killyleagh has this week claimed the scheme has the overwhelming support of local people.The claim by Ravenblack Developments comes after the National Trust voiced a huber of concerns about the scale and potential impact the poundm project could have on Strangford LoughLocal politicians are supporting the plan and have called on the Planning Service to decidethey are also prepared to back the scheme and approve an application to build up to  new homes, a new -berth marina and a nursing home.In the wake of the National Trust criticisms, which include claims the scheme is ldquovisually intrusive and damaging to the environment, a spokesman for the developers said it was important to set the record straight.Mr Roy Redmond, the companyrsquos development manager, said Ravenblack hopes it will not be ldquoneedlessly prevented from delivering something that can only be good for the town and its surrounding areas.CLOUGH ndash Education chiefs have agreed to issue a vesting order to acquire a plot of land for a new Clough Primary School.At last weekrsquos meeting of the South Eastern Education and Library Board, members agreed that they should use their powers to acquire a plot adjacent to the school.The land is owned by Clough Presbyterians Church Trustees, who are supportive of the proposal but are unable to hand over the land because of legal restrictions.The site will be used for construction of a new school which will cater for the amalgamation of Clough Primary School with nearby Dundrum Primary School.The decision to merge the schools was taken following ain numbers in Dundrum and increasing pressure on resources in Clough.Meanwhile, the Board has also proposed a special unit for children with special and language dficulties should also be established at the Clough school.BALLYNAHINCH ndash The doors to one of the districtrsquos newest nursery schools were officially opened during a ceremony in Ballynahinch last week.Staff and children at Magheradroll Nursery School in Main Street have been working quietly behind the scenes since the cross-community nursery first opened last September.But  months later they have launched the school in a pre-Christmas celebration.Local education officials, including South Eastern Education and Library Board chief executive Jackie Fitzsimons, were among the guests invited to the opening along with Down Council chairwoman Anne McAleenan..prettyPhoto

title: Hinch play out dramatic win against Dromore in cup
story: BALLYNAHINCH continued their quest for another Junior Cup with a hard fought victory over derby rivals Dromore.The game was far removed from the dominant victory in the corresponding league fixture earlier in the season and Ballynahinch had to draw on all their cup experience to get the result.They played into the conditions in the first half and were in full control of the match at half time as excellent ball retention and carrying from the likes of Gareth Gill, Matthew Connolly and Stuart Evans and two superb Ronan Patterson finishes gave them a four-point lead at the break.When Harry McCormick scored early in the second half to take the score to -, the win looked a formality.But as is so often the case at Ballymacarn Park it proved dficult to play with the conditions and some poor decision making and wayward kicking kept inviting Dromore on to the counter-attack.They duly obliged with two quick converted tries to take a - lead and suddenly there was a game on again.Keith Dickson put the home team ahead again with a try and Matthew Nortonrsquos third conversion of the day meant that Dromore had to find another try to regain the lead.As the game headed into the closing minutes the visitors managed to cross the Hinch line and looked set to claim a famous victory as they lead - going into injury time.However, indiscipline was to cost them as they gave away a penalty at the death.Ballynahinch spurned the chance of a draw and kicked for the corner to go for glory and Conor Phillips delivered the winning score in the opposite corner to win a great match.The quarter-finals draw contains most of the big names but Ballynahinch will be full of confidence going forward.Ballynahinch : John Dickson, Conor Piper, Harry McCormick, Stuart Evans, Matthew Connolly, Keith Dickson, Stephen Campbell, Gareth Gill, Chris Gibson, Matthew Norton, Ronan Patterson, Eamon McAnulty, Marcus Heath, Connor Phillips, Paddy Wright, Matthew Cooper, Ben McMullan..prettyPhoto

title: Lowden Guitars given royal approval by Charles and Ed
story: ACCLAIMED by pop royalty and real-le royalty, George Lowdenrsquos guitars are known to be the best in the world.The Prince of Wales recently made known his knowledge of and fascination with Georgersquos guitars and Ed Sheeran reportedly likes to keep one handy in nearly every room of his house.With Niall Horan of One Direction and Dubliner singer songwriter Dermot Kennedy becoming the latest owners of the bespoke guitars, Georgersquos company, Lowden Guitars, has just announced its latest collaboration with Sheeran.To celebrate the release of his most recent album, Sheeran has teamed up with George, who founded the firm in , to design and create a signature guitar worthy of music royalty.The Sheeran by Lowden Equals Edition guitar will also be available to the public to purchase, with a limited edition run of , available through Lowdenrsquos global dealer network.Itrsquos the second joint project with Sheeran, following on from their range of more affordable guitars.The latest achievement comes in the wake of George recently meeting the Prince of Wales at a Windsor Castle reception to mark Lowden Guitars winning the  Queenrsquos Awards for Enterprise.He also launched a new range of limited edition guitars to mark his th birthday over the summer which features specications chosen by George.Itrsquos all a far cry from when the renowned luthier first began to hand-make guitars for his own use.He could never have known that his determination to make the best guitar would see his name travel around the world and be spoken of by royalty.ldquoTherersquos quite a lot of things that have happened that I never could have imagined. When I started out, I had no formal training in the manufacture of guitars, explained George.ldquoIn a way, that gave me the confidence to take some risks, innovate and produce an instrument that has a completely unique voicing.He found the Prince of Wales to be very interested in the guitarsrsquo manufacture and may have even suggested a new development.ldquoWe had a great chat and he asked quite a lot of questions about the wood, all kinds and how we found it, said George.ldquoHe was also very interested in dieback ash, asking aboutit would be a very good way to use the trees as a lot have perished due to this disease.ldquoIt wouldnrsquot be the best toned wood you could find but Irsquove been thinking more about that since and wondering whether we could use it for guitar necks or not so we might do a little experiment to seeit works.From creating coveted instruments for top Irish and UK guitarists in the know, Lowden Guitars have become an international sales success mdash hence the Queenrsquos Award.George explained: ldquoThe company is far bigger than I ever envisaged. In some ways itrsquos good but I never tried to expand the company and get the kind of growth we have enjoyed. It just kind of happened over the years as organic growth which has been great.His guitars tend to sell by word of mouth from musician to musician and the actual experience of playing a Lowden and relishing its distinct tones at first hand.ldquoWherever in the world where we sell, we are still quite a niche, upper end company so the guitars are at the highest price level in all of the countries, said George.ldquoItrsquos a natural process where people see the guitars for the first time. They go into a shop and then over a period of a few years the reputation builds within that country. Our presence also grows and then we move into more specialist guitar shops, so it all takes time.ldquoI remember as a teenager I was mad keen to get a Gibson  which I saw in Matchettrsquos shop window in Belfast all those years ago and I couldnrsquot afford it.ldquoIf something is really good, and the young player comes in and plays it but canrsquot afford it, it goes into his or her mind and later on they find a way to afford it.George says the Covid pandemic has not impact on sales, although it has had other consequences.George said: ldquoIt didnrsquot impact on us for sales as our order book remained very firm but it was more to do with making the guitars as we had to completely re-organise the factory for better social distancing which was very expensive.ldquoWe had to close down the factory for a while in order to do that and more with people having to isolate it proved challenging..prettyPhoto

title: Magpies fly high in Breffni Park
story: DOWN kingpins Kilcoo qualied for an Ulster semi-final after a good performance at Kingspan Breffni Park on Saturday evening, defeating Cavan-based Ramor United by  points.The Magpies, reigning Ulster champions, will meet Glen of Derry in the last four in what will be a massive clash in two weeks time.It was tit-for-tat early on but the home side got a massive confidence boost in the fth minute via a well taken Sean McEvoy goal, their most impressive performer on the night.Kilcoorsquos response was emphatic though, firstly Ceilum Doherty stuck over a nice point and then that man Jerome Johnston done what he does best and fired to the net to put his side into a lead they would never relinquish.Further scores from Ryan McEvoy, Shealan Johnston and Doherty again sent them in four up at the water-break.The second period of the first half turned out to be poor affair with both sides missing good scoring chances. However, the Magpies led by four on referee Niall Cullenrsquos short whistle.Ramor came out after the break and pressed high, and were rewarded with three scores in the first five minutes.Kilcoo didnrsquot panic and upped the ante immediately with two Paul Devlin frees settling things. Jerome Johnston and Eugene Branagan kept the scoreboard ticking and on the th minute the brilliant Ceilum Doherty found the net after great approach play by Dylan Ward.From here to the end, Kilcoo kept playing with that high tempo and the game was put beyond the Virginia men with six minutes remaining when man of the match Jerome Johnston found the net once again.Both sides emptied their benches as the game petered out, as the Down men came away with an impressive win.Mickey Moran and his management team will take great heart from many aspects of their teamrsquos performance and will know only too well it will take this and morethey are to win against the Derry champions and reach back-to-back Ulster finals.Kilcoo assistant manager Conleith Gilligan expressed mixed emotions as the local side look ahead to the semi-final stage.ldquoThere was definitely some nice passages of play and, look, we were able to play the game at our own pace and as the competition goes on that wonrsquot be allowed to happen, he said.ldquoOnce we got our legs moving, up to the first water-break we did very well. It was just that second quarter where we were on top but we didnrsquot take enough chances that would have put the game to bed and we allowed Ramor to live in the game right up to half-time.He added: ldquoWe didnrsquot need to be the best in the country tonight, we just needed to be better than Ramor and I think we were.Kilcoo: N Kane, N Branagan, R McEvoy , A Branagan, M Rooney, Anthony Morgan , E Branagan , D Ward , Aaron Morgan, C Doherty , J Johnston , S Johnston , C Laverty, R Johnston, P Devlin .Subs used: A Branagan, T Fettes, M Hynes, C Rooney and J Clarke.Ramor United: L Brady D Bartley, B OrsquoConnell, E Somerville A OrsquoConnell, Jack Brady, M Magee, L Caffrey, E Maguire B Smith, S Cadden, C MaguireJames Brady , A Cole, S McEvoy .Subs used: G Mannion, K Maguire, P McNamee , J Bradley and L Lynch.Referee: Niall Cullen ..prettyPhoto

title: New £65m Lidl supermarket in Carryduff gets green light
story: THE green light has been given for the multi-million pound regeneration of the Carryduff shopping centre which could create  new jobs.The ambitious plan designed to transform the Church Road site mdash which includes a new pound.m Lidl store mdash was approved by Lisburn and Castlereagh Councilrsquos Planning Committee on Monday.Lidl submitted its new store planning application earlier this year and hopes to open the , square metre facility, creating  new jobs and parking spaces for  vehicles, by the middle of next year.In addition to the Lidl store, an additional , square metres of floorspace is available for other retailers at the expansive centre site.The new store opening is a major part of the shopping centrersquos regeneration, which has lain derelict for more than four years, with the planning application proposing the demolition of the existing buildings and the erection of three retail units, cafe, bookmakers, drive through cafe, landscaping and associated site works.Parking provision for disabled drivers is included in the development proposal alongside dedicated spaces for parents and children. Four dedicated spaces for electrical vehicles are also included.Itrsquos understood that in addition to the  jobs in the new Lidl store, a further  will be created across the other proposed retail units, with  jobs created during construction and development.Council planners are recommending to members that the application be approved with  conditions including its full construction within a five-year period.In papers submitted ahead of Mondayrsquos planning meeting, planners said they were recommending approval as the proposed retail use is considered to comply with the local development plan.They say that when the buildings are constructed, they will not adversely impact on the character of the area or have a detrimental impact on the amenity of existing residents in properties adjoining the site.ldquoAppropriate provision is made to meet the needs of cyclists and adequate facilities are made for shower and changing facilities as required for such a major employment-generating development, the papers point out.A spokesperson for Lidl said the poundm store would reflect the retailerrsquos concept design, boasting a sales floor, a shopping environment withspacious, wide aisles, long tills, restrooms and baby-changing facilities, as well as a bakery offering and staff facilities.ldquoOur ambitious plans to complement the site with additional retail and leisure units represent an investment of more than pound million into the area and the support of more than  jobs, he said.ldquoWersquore proud to be part of the centrersquos signicant regeneration and bring a new future of growth to the locality whilst honouring the sitersquos historical connections to the community.The spokesman added: ldquoWe hope to receive planning permission for the site and look forward to opening the brand new, state-of-the-art Lidl store early next year, bringing shoppers even more choice of quality products at unbeatable value.Carryduff shopping centre was a prime retail destination for many years, but since the closure of its flagship Supervalu store in , it struggled to attract an anchor tenant that would drive its growth.The formal planning application by Lidl follows an extensive local consultation of the plans undertaken in February which was positively received by local representatives and the wider community.Lidl acquired the . acre Carryduff shopping centre site in August last year as part of the retailerrsquos plans to expand its store presence across the region to more than  stores by the end of the decade..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle harbour development plans
story: THE redevelopment of the former generator house at Newcastle harbour has the potential to act as a catalyst to secure additional investment.Thatrsquos the assertion of Mournes councillor Willie Clarke whose comment came after Monday eveningrsquos annual meeting of the Newcastle Harbour Heritage Association.He congratulated the grouprsquos chairman Campbell Miller and the committee members on the ldquofantastic positive contribution they have made in improving the harbour over the past year.Cllr Clarke said the two main items discussed at the annual meeting included the refurbishment of the former generator house as a community hub and the provision of a new boarding pontoon that would allow disabled people to board vessels, something which he said is long overdue.The business case for the new floating pontoon recently passed through Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.Cllr Clarke explained the vision for the generator house includes the provision of showers, toilets, and changing facilities for water-based recreation, alongside a meeting room for the community and harbour users.He said the business case was submitted to the local authority and approved through the so-called community transfer process.ldquoIt is essential that this building is refurbished for the local community which will be a catalyst in the development of the harbour, suggested Cllr Clarke.ldquoIn addition, it offers an excellent opportunity for the local council and the harbour community to develop a partnership to create a community hub for the area. I will be facilitating meetings with council officials to progress this vital community asset as quickly as possible.Cllr Clarke said there was no doubt that with an ldquoambitious and focused vision for the future, the harbour area could become a unique attraction, meeting the needs of not just the local community, but also become an exciting destination for those who visit Newcastle..prettyPhoto

title: Red High hurlers through to final
story: THE first half of this Danske Bank Mageean Cup semi-final was brilliant to watchthere were any neutrals around.If you were a supporter of either St Patrickrsquos or St Louisrsquo, it was nail-biting, edge-of-the-seat drama played at a blistering pace with top class scoring at each end.That half finished - to - in favour of the Ballymena side.For the Red High management of Darren Swail, Sean Paul Gibson and Danny Toner, the entertainment factor had to be sacriced to get the result they needed.Bringing Oisin Coulter back as extra cover in defence curtailed the damage that Ballymenarsquos two Loughgiel inside forwards had done in the opening half, but it also meant that the Red Highrsquos attack would struggle to retain ball to keep the scoreboard running.Jack McCloskey had scored - in the first half and Roacutenaacuten McCollam -. McCollam fired over another point in the th minute and pointed a free at the very end while trying to it in on the Downpatrick area to poach a late goal.McCloskey didnrsquot score in the second half and being out of general play resulted in his normally reliable free-taking also taking a hit.At the other end the outnumbered Downpatrick forwards had to survive on scraps as well but they could always rely on their free-takers.Goalkeeper Pearse Smyth landed two points from inside his own half, while Tom McGrattan converted three frees and landed a point from play as well.McGrattan was the star of the game and he capped a brilliant inidual performance with two late plays that effectively took his team into the final.With the game in the balance at - each in the rd minute, McGrattan jinked his way along the sideline under the stand to win himself a free.It was an acute angle, but the Portaferry clubman arrowed the sliotar between the uprights.Then less than a minute later he played a beautul cross-field pass into the path of mid-fielder Finn Turpin, who stepped inside the defender and hit the roof of the net from  metres out.St Patrickrsquos were through to their first ever Danske Bank Mageean Cup final where they will play St Patrickrsquos Maghera at the Dub Arena on Friday week, December .But back again to that breath-taking first half.After five minutes, the teams had each scored three points. By the tenth minute, Jack McCloskey had cut through the Red High cover and shot to the net off the base of the right hand post.Within three minutes Downpatrick were a point up. McGrattan went around the left side of the Ballymena defence at full pace to rle to the roof of the net for one of the best goals that you will see at any level.Aodhan McGarry responded by pointing from a side-line and the water-break broke the action at - each.McGarry started the second quarter scoring with a fine point but a run of three successive scores from Finn Turpin, McGrattan and Oisin Coulter edged the Red High ahead again.However, three frees from Jack McCloskey and a point from Ronan McCollam put Ballymena in the lead by - to - at half-time.By the second water break Downpatrick were - to - ahead, mainly through frees and St Louisrsquo were now looking for scores from distance.The next  minutes went scoreless. In hindsight Ballymena snatched at a couple of scoring chances that might have put pressure on the eventual winners who pumped a lot of ball in high on the north Antrim defence with no .Eventually sub Tom McFerran brought the teams level and McCollam from the left wing gave St Louisrsquo the lead. The gauntlet had been thrown down for the Red High.Oisin Coulter landed a much-needed Downpatrick point in reply and they held firm until Tom McGrattan delivered the match-winning scores.It is scant consolation for Ballymena that they played their part in a fine display of schoolsrsquo hurling, but a number of players stood out including Daire McMullan, Connor Dickson and Dara Martin in defence and McCollam and McCloskey in attack until tempered by Downpatrickrsquos packed back line.Defence was ultimately the winning of the game, but they would not have got across the line without Turpin, Oisin Coulter and especially the mercurial Tom McGrattan.As a hurling disciple of the great Bro Charles in the s, I was a proud man leaving the Dub on Friday evening.For the generations of hurlers who climbed to the top of the hill on Saul Street each morning over the past  or  years, winning a Mageean was just not on the radar.This team is only  minutes from achieving what for us was the impossible.St Patrickrsquos: P Smyth - frees, J Ruddy, R OrsquoNeill, D Coulter, S Mageean, D Mallon, C Lenaghan, T Connolly -, F Turpin -, M Dorrian -, A Connolly, T McGrattan - , O Coulter -, R McGrath, S McCarthy.Subs: F MacManus for A Connolly , LMcCabe for S McCarthy , F Casey for R McGrath ..prettyPhoto

title: Road officials set to carry out survey at Ballynahinch school
story: PLANS by roads officials to carry out a survey on the main road outside Ballynahinch Primary School have been welcomed by Strangford MLA Peter Weir.The work will be carried out to assess the potential for a new pedestrian crossing and while pleased that the survey is to take place, Mr Weir is disappointed that there are no current plans to also introduce a temporary mph speed limit at the Dromore Road as part of a province-wide Department for Infrastructure initiative.Mr Weir mdash who has met with school principal Mr Michael Moore mdash said the safety of children who have to cross the busy road was of paramount importance and a real issue of concern for parents and residents.The former Education Minister said he was ldquodisappointed that the school had not been included in the Roads Departmentrsquos part-time mph speed limit scheme.ldquoI believe that the Department needs to give a clear commitment that Ballynahinch Primary School will be included in the next roll-out of the scheme, said Mr Weir.ldquoThe Dromore Road is busy and is also a bus route. Given that the primary school is located off this road, many motorists may not even realise they are passing a school as they drive along.Mr Weir said while he welcomed the assessment into the potential for a dedicated pedestrian crossing, he will continue to press for road safety improvements outside the school.In their response, roads officials say there is high demand on the Department for Infrastructure to introduce traffic calming measures at ious locations on the road network and that each request is considered carefully.They point out that schemes for such measures are prioritised, taking into account collision history, vehicle speeds, traffic volumes, road geometry and the character of the specic location to ensure that limited available finance is targeted to those sites in most need.Engineers point out that the Dromore Road is within the mph speed limit and, unfortunately, would not be suitable for traffic calming measures in the form of speed bumps.They say there are already existing mph gateway signs in place and also red textured surfacing on the Dromore Road which is also served by existing street lighting.ldquoAt present, for a mph speed limit, no additional traffic calming measures can be provided at this time, they said in a letter, confirming that an assessment for the provision of a pedestrian crossing in the vicinity of the primary school will take place..prettyPhoto

title: Santas come riding into town
story: THE th annual Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride took place on Saturday.It was freezing cold with occasional rain showers, but it certainly didnt dampen the spirits of the Santas taking part or the crowds of men, women and children who lined Main Street to greet them.The children were overwhelmed with excitement when they saw Santa getting out of his carriage at the Christmas tree and he certainly had surprises for them in his sack.Hugo Duncan, Boxcar Brian and Gerard Dornan provided top drawer entertainment. Hugo kept the craic going and all three sang some Christmas favourites.Ride organiser Joan Cunningham said afterwards: ldquoIt was all simply fantastic.Joan thanks everyone who helped in any way to make the day such a success, including the PSNI, and also wishes everyone a happy Christmas and a peaceful New Year..prettyPhoto

title: Success at Seeley
story: NEARLY  runners took part on in the Joe Seeley Memorial k which doubled as the NI  Ulster Road K Championships.This annual event hosted by Willowfield and Temperance Harriers did not take place last year due to Covid and was sorely missed by runners and spectators alike.The Seeley Cup is seen as the culmination of the NI road running calendar while East Down ACrsquos flagship Jimmyrsquos  event is viewed as the season opener.It is a good time to mention that the EDAC race is due to open for entry later this month. Jimmyrsquos  is scheduled to take place on Sunday, March , and it is anticipated that interest will be high especially given that the Seeley Cup sold out well in advance.The Joe Seeley offers a flat and fast course starting on the Ormeau Embankment in Belfast with two and a bit laps through the Ormeau Park.For those watching or racing it was a sharp cold day, but miraculously the heavy rain and high winds that preceded the .pm start died down just in time to let the runners have a fair crack at a good performance.At the pointy end there were small clusters of runners who made a break early on in the first lap and then a lead group of five formed as they headed out for the second lap. The huddle of five then broke apart in the last K as they hurtled towards the finish line in break neck speed.Overall winner Owen Everardonly edged for glory in the last two strides as right to the mat it was not clear who would breach the tape first.His time of . was two seconds ahead of Matthew Neill , who was one second ahead of third-placed Eskander Turki . The top  competitors were all sub  minutes for K, which is fast by any means.East Down ACrsquos Neil McCartan, who prefers shorter distances and would choose track over road running, finished in a commendable .. This is not a personal best time, but given that this is his first serious attempt at a K in three years he will be more than satisfied. This got him well inside the top  in th place.Neil Curran reaped the rewards of his consistent cross-country racing, converting the stamina gained in that discipline to a strong road performance. He was chuffed to take  seconds off his previous best time and at . is well poised to run a sub  minute K in the near future.He said that he ran conservatively off the start as he was fearful of overcooking it and as a result ended up running solo for a large part of the distance. This is a hard way to race, but gives him plenty to work with in his next event.Junior titleMackenzie Murray was taking on his first ever K and well warned to pace it carefully, he ran a superb race in .. Many runners set sub  minutes for K as a good base goal, but he smashed that and some.He was even more delighted to discover that he was the quickest junior athlete on the day by well over a minute. As mentioned this race stood as the NI  Ulster Championship, so he gains that title as well as a Seeley Cup age group win.A great achievement.It was actually a hat trick as he also snatched bragging rights in the Murray family as his dad Dee and mum Janine were also racing on the day.Dee was next home for EDAC in a very respectable .. Dee has been troubled by niggles and was not even surehe was going to start let alone finish, so being able to take part was more important than the result.Seamus Savage who was the next EDAC finisher is training hard to regain fitness and based on his current form he went in not expecting too much.While he enjoyed the race, he found it tough in the latter half. He can take his time of . as a bench mark as he aims to work on his speed in the coming months.The ladiesThe overall standard of the female field compared well with the menrsquos with the top lady coming home in .. Ann-Marie McGlynnis an experienced runner who as a Veteran Over  showed that age is no barrier in her case.Aoe Kilgallonin . and Nakita Burkein . completed the podium.EDACrsquos interest lay with their own three runners. Leanne Spick having recently completed her first cross-country was keen to try her first K. She is enjoying being part of a club and the support that this garners.She reacted well to the shouts of encouragement and finished sub  minutes, a bit ahead of Janine Murray who recorded . despite a hamstring niggle.While the Seeley Cup is seen as a fast race it is also inclusive with many targeting the distance rather than a specic time. Sam Anderson was glad of the cheers of club mates as she battled to the finish in one hour and seven minutes. Another race ticked off by this consistent attender. Good work by all three.Cross-countryThe Robinson brothers, Oliver and Alex, ended off their  cross-country season with a trip to the Uneven Age Group All Irelands Cross Country in Gowran, Kilkenny, on Sunday.The sun shone all day but the temperature stayed low with the ground remaining icy in parts. Alex had gained his Ulster U- team place by coming sixth at the Ulster  NI race in Donegal a few weeks previously, so he had set his expectations high.His race was ,m around a very twisty course through long grass, all of which made it more technical than previous races.The start of any cross-country race is hectic with lots of jostling and this was no exception.Alex was pulled back when the gun went off and then had to contend with some fallers so he never really got into his stride.He was disappointed to place th out of a field of  runners, but deserves huge credit for his commitment over the last few months.Alexrsquos older brother, Oliver, was running for the Down team in the U- race. He was probably one of the youngest in the -strong field, having celebrated his th birthday a few days beforehand, so had no expectations and therefore maybe put less pressure on himself.He had a great run in the end, taking one minute and  seconds off his previous road k personal best and completing the course in .. He finished th and was the second Down team member home.Both boys have done their club proud and their parents also deserve medals for acting as support crew on multiple weekends. They will all be glad of a rest before racing resumes in January.Dillon in KGavin Hynds, as a long term member of East Down AC, was delighted when his son, Dillon, decided to follow in his footsteps by signing up to the EDAC junior section.Dillon has been attending sessions since September and gaining confidence each week, so when his school, Our Lady and St Patrick Primary, announced a fundraiser k fun run and walk he felt that he might be fit to take part as a runner.On Saturday morning despite the horrible weather conditions, he set off to the RGU in Downpatrick with Gavin as his sidekick. K is a long way at Dillonrsquos age, but to give him his due he stuck at it and made it to the finish with a bit of encouragement from his dad. Super effort Dillon!.prettyPhoto

title: Town manager could help find financial support for businesses
story: A NUMBER of business owners have revealed that it is dficult for them to find out what potential funding opportunities are open to them.The issue was raised at a special event in Downpatrick last week as part of the Northern Ireland Executiversquos initiative to examine the future of high streets in towns and villages across the province.Members of a Stormont task force spearheading a new initiative met with business owners and elected representatives at Denvirrsquos Coaching Inn for a workshop designed to provide them with an opportunity to have their say on how to rejuvenate town centres in a post-Covid world.Designed to help make town, city and village centres places where people can do business, socialise, shop, be creative and use public services, the task force initiative is determined to make a dference, with its membership including a raft of government departments and key organisations including Retail NI and Hospitality Ulster.During the two-hour event, some from the Downpatrick business community said they find it dficult to access information on what financial support is potentially available to them and they donrsquot know who to turn to for help.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is currently consulting traders in Downpatrick about the potential of appointing a town centre manager while another suggestion tabled at last weekrsquos meeting was the creation of a new business improvement group.In addition, it was also suggested that shoppers should be allowed to park in dedicated loading bays in the town centre on Saturdays when they are not in use.The new Stormont initiative recognises that every high street is dferent and has its own character, personality and needs that will each require bespoke local solutions, with people asked to put forward ideas on what success in high streets could look like, with the focus on family friendly destinations where people want to shop, socialise, live and work.Last weekrsquos event in Downpatrick has been described as ldquointeresting by local councillor Dermot Curran, who said he understood the ldquoconcerns of those in the business community who have no one or no recognised body to help them understand what potential funding opportunities are available to them.He went on: ldquoDiscussions are continuing about a town centre manager but no final decision has been made. In my opinion, such an appointment is crucial and could benefit the town and the business community a great deal.ldquoThe night time economy is one area that needs to be improved not only in Downpatrick but where, but rapid progress this in the current Covid climate may not be possible.ldquoHowever, there is no reason why ideas to regenerate our night time economy cannot be discussed now to lay plans for the future, he continued.Cllr Curran said every high street is dferent, with many people keen to see them become vibrant shopping hubs at the heart of local communities, explaining that the work of the Stormont task force could not be more timely.He added: ldquoAnything that can be done to increase footfall in our town centres in the future will be more than welcome.The call for evidence document is available at https:www.executiveoffice-ni.gov.uk consultations call-evidence-high-street-task-force, while responses to the call for evidence can be made to highstreet@communities-ni.gov.uk..prettyPhoto

title: avian influenza housing order come force
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityNew housing measures are to be introduced as part of the Avian Influenza Prevention Zone in Northern Irelandfrom November , Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots has announced.The decision to introduce a housing order follows the confirmation of  cases of Highly-Pathogenic Avian InfluenzaHN across Great Britain and one case in a commercial turkey flock in Co. Monaghan.DAERA officials have also confirmed, late last night, the presence of Avian Influenza in two wild birds retrieved from the Belfast Waterworks site earlier this week.Disease control zones have been put in place around all infected premises to mitigate against onward disease spread.Under the new housing measures, all bird keepers in NI will be legally required to keep their birds indoors or otherwise separate from wild birds, and to follow strict biosecurity measures.This applies to owners of pet birds, commercial flocks or just a few birds in a backyard or hobby flock.Announcing the decision to introduce a housing order, Minister Poots said: ldquoI took the decision to introduce the new housing measures in order to try to prevent an incursion of avian influenza into the poultry flock in Northern Ireland.ldquoIt is now a legal requirement for all poultry and captive bird keepers to keep their birds housed or otherwise separate from wild birds.ldquoThis decision was based on sound expert advice and in consultation with industry.ldquoThis decision to house is an additional step to the Avian Influenza Prevention Zoneintroduced on November , and is another necessary precautionary measure requiring all bird keepers to keep their birds housed.ldquoThese housing measures build on the strengthened biosecurity measures that were brought in as part of the AIPZ.ldquoSince my decision to introduce the housing order, we have now discovered avian flu in two wild birds in Belfast ndash that tells us unequivocally that the disease is already here and in our wild bird population.ldquoKeeping it out of the commercial flocks is now down to our poultry sector and the measures they take to keep the disease out.ldquoAdhering to, and a constant review of, all biosecurity measures is the best weapon we have to avoid an incursion.ldquoMy officials will continue to liaise closely with stakeholders and colleagues in GB and the Republic as the situation develops.To assist all bird keepers in complying with the new rules, a Biosecurity self-assessment tool has been developed that is available on the DAERA website.If avian influenza were to enter NI, the disease would have a signicant and devastating impact on our poultry industry, international trade and the wider economy.Poultry and captive bird keepers are advised to be vigilant for any signs of disease in their birds and any wild birds, and to seek prompt advice from their vetthey have any concerns.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards title: government policy is to lockdown and wait for vaccine which doesnt seem to have worked as well as expected
story: Crowds flock to marvel at NI’s Christmas Drive   Donaldson repeats threat to bring down StormontNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionGovernment policy is to lockdown and wait for vaccine which doesn’t seem to have worked as well as expectedA letter from Brian Gibson:By The NewsroomFriday, th December , : am  "       "  Letter to the editorFor many folk the question in their mind is am I going to be able to celebrate Christmas For others it is now: am I going to be able to enter a cafe and buy a cup of coffee or even told to stay at home Government policy all along appears to have been lock everyone down wait for a vaccine which doesn’t seem to have worked as well as expected.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Therefore now exclude those who weren’t comfortable with vaccinations in the first place.I had the Covid virus myself about eight weeks ago along with five family members. I was chased from my home to an empty house within in the family, as we had health care professionals in our home that needed protectingI was not sureI had Covid until I lost taste and smell after a week or so I got the bigger PCR test and it was positive.I got a message asking about my recent contacts I replied none as I had already been isolating for over a week, and that was it.What puzzles me is that you don’t get any follow up or any offers of help while you are isolating with the sword of Damocles hanging over you, wonderingyou will get better or worse around the -day mark ,which seems to be a signicant Covid time period.I know everyone is very busy and I accept that but other countries send out little boxes with anti viral drugs paracetamol etc as a preventative including countries that we consider less developed like Mexico and a province in India with a population three times bigger than the UK.If you mention this antiviral anti-parasitic drug in question by name you could find yourself cancelled on social media.Has anyone noticed that Covid has gone away in Japan  Cases in Japan were going through the roof after the Olympics but started dropping to virtually nothing  days after the aforementioned unmentionable anti viral drug was legalised approved for use in Japan! Perhaps just a coincidence I simply would like to know why we didn’t try some preventative care and why not now even this late in the gameI heard one family GP on television pleading for antiviral drugs and asking when she might be able to prescribe them to her patients Rather we find ourselves two years on, Christmas under threat, a subsection of society being excluded and still being promised more of the same for next year Brian Gibson, Comber——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: simon bryne should focus on his two officers welfare and return them to normal duties
story: Sinn Fein Arts Minister slammed for failing to give a single penny to mark Northern Ireland Centenary   Donaldson repeats threat to bring down StormontNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionSimon Bryne should focus on his two officers’ welfare andthem to normal dutiesA letter from Robin Newton MLA:By LettersFriday, th December , : am  "       "  Letter to the editorThe incident in which two young PSNI officers at a Covid incident on Belfast’s Ormeau Road, then were considered for prosecution, was bewildering. The background to the incident has been well detailed in the media. However, central to the incident is that it took place at the scene of dreadful murders in a bookmakers shop. It is right that all police actions are open to scrutiny. But that the officers were subject to a republican propaganda campaign in the heat of which the chief constable’s support for his officers was absent was deeply disappointing.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The chief constable’s approach added to community concerns around the even-handedness of policing. There are many questions around the handling of this case that demand answers. However, the well-being of the young officers should now be the chief constable’s primary concern. Simon Byrne must ensure that PSNI support services offer assistance as the officers resume normal duties. Also, an apology from the chief constable to the police officers might be appropriate. Robin Newton MBE, MLA, DUP, East Belfast——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: those employed on the public payroll are insulated from the uncertainty the private sector has to endure from covid policy
story: Sinn Fein Arts Minister slammed for failing to give a single penny to mark Northern Ireland Centenary   Donaldson repeats threat to bring down StormontNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionThose employed on the public payroll are insulated from the uncertainty the private sector has to endure from Covid policyA letter from Adrian Lonergan:By LettersFriday, th December , : am  "       "  Letter to the editorIt was interesting to hear Allegra Stratton reflect upon the public backlash when it was brought to their attention a Christmas partytook place in Downing Street last year. During her resignation speech, Ms Stratton acknowledged the ‘anger and frustration’ of members of the public as they struggled with their businesses because of government restrictions. What this highlights is the casual outlook some have towards these restrictions until it is they who are impacted directly by them.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Whether it is politicians, special advisors, the civil service and the wider public sector, those who are employed on the public payroll are insulated from the uncertainty that the private sectorhas to endure from government policy. Only when their positions are threatened, as Ms Stratton has found out, do they begin to understand the ‘anger and frustration’. Ms Stratton will find another well remunerated position in the London media. The same, however, cannot be said for everyone  who have lost their livelihoods over the past eighteen months.Adrian Lonergan, Belfast, BT——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: anthem debate detracting from northern ireland fans success trevor ringland
story: Irish language row: ‘Street signs mean area is Nationalist’ says DUP representative   Sinn Fein rising star quit over paymentsNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleAnthem debate detracting from Northern Ireland fans’ success: Trevor RinglandThe latest debate over the use of God Save The Queen at Northern Ireland football internationals should not distract from the fan-driven success at creating a welcoming and all-inclusive atmosphere at Windsor Park, Trevor Ringland has said.By Mark RaineyThursday, th December , : pm  "       "  International friendly, Windsor Park, Belfast on    - Northern Ireland vs Korea Republic. Photo: ©INPHO Presseye William CherrySparked by the broadcast of a UTV documentary earlier this week – exploring the views of key figures in the international set up past and present - a number of media commentators have also aired their views on the subject of the anthem, with many calling for it to be replaced, or jointly used with The Solider’s Song to recognise the community background of the players from the nationalist tradition.However, former Irish rugby international Trevor Ringland has said the isive debate over the anthem is deflecting attention away from where it should be – on the fans’ unrivalled efforts to prevent any sectarian attitudes from the past poisoning the cross-community culture around the Windsor Park of today.“The key thing for the Northern Ireland football fans is to be recognised for the tremendous work they have done and to keep doing it,” he said.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.“The way they challenged themselves to change was fantastic. They are the one group of people on this island that have done it.“Northern Ireland fans know there are young nationalists playing for the team, and they really respect that those young nationalists have declared for Northern Ireland, they want them to be out on the pitch, they want all of the young people in Northern Ireland to aspire to play for Northern Ireland, and they have worked really hard at creating an atmosphere that is friendly and a lot of young nationalists appreciate that.”He also said there are those who resent the fact that Northern Ireland football fans have “proved that sectarianism can be tackled” and that “the rest of the island need to follow their example”.Mr Ringland said his unionist background did not prevent him from recognising the Irish national anthem used for rugby internationals.“When I played rugby for Ireland we stood out of respect for The Soldier’s Song. But it was a dferent Soldier’s Song – it was not wrapped around the IRA, it was one of friendship and one of a group of people who wanted us to be out there on the pitch representing them,” he said.“Would I suggest that we look at a sporting anthem as well [at football internationals], to play in addition to God Save The Queen  I would say we did that in rugby and it works really well, because it is an extension of that constructive atmosphere.“In the medium term anyway, and maybe forever, God Save The Queen might well be played, but it would be nice to have something  [also],” Mr Ringland added.READ: Windsor Park : worst night of sectarian thuggery that never wasREAD: Opinion:  match a case study in nationalist myth making ——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
